photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/359366.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The family requests that this be in regular rotation!  It is one of the best italian casseroles we've ever had.  I agree with previous reviewers that success of this dish is dependent on the sauce that you use.  I use two jars of Classico Spicy Tomato & Basil.  I stick with the sour cream and cheeses recommended in the recipe and think this is fabulous.  I am a huge ricotta cheese fan, but for this recipe, the sour cream / provolone + mozzarella hits the mark perfectly.  Because this does make such a big dish, I buy a deep dish disposable 13x9 aluminum pan so it all fits.  I also like not having to wash a pan with mozzarella cheese stuck all over things at the end.  

I also layered this a bit differently based on other reviewer suggestions.  I save a little bit (say ~ 1/5 of one jar of sauce) that I put on the bottom of the pan, then put a layer of ziti on that, cover with the tomato / meat mixture, then sour cream, then cheese, and repeat.  I ended up with 3 layers, but it all depends on how thick you make your layers and the size of your pan.  The casserole does not have any dry spots this way.  

I'm sure it will be very good with other variations; italian sausage, ground turkey, etc., but you do not need to change one thing!  Thank you Colleen for such a great dish!

text:
This was much better than I expected. I have never made this particular dish, but have tried it when others have made it and always found it dry. I think, what sets this one apart is the amount of sauce. It keeps it plenty moist while baking. I dislike jarred pasta sauce, so I used some of The Best Marinara Sauce Yet from the site. I then stretched it with some blended tomato sauce, diced tomatoes, tomato paste, dried parsley, garlic powder, mushroom spaghetti seasoning, and a little white wine. I just measured out the 52oz in a large measuring cup. I made it the night before and it filled a 13x9 pan to the very top. Only other change I made was using all mozzarella and rotini pasta I had on hand. I also used reduced fat sour cream, in which I was short about 1/4 cup, and 1.5 lbs of lean beef I needed to use up. This recipe seems pretty forgiving. I baked it for 1 hour, because I was taking it from the fridge overnight, and kept foil on it the whole time while baking. This would be great when family visits.

None
text:
love this so much! been using this as my "go-to" recipe when i have company for years. i use the following modifications from someone else's comments:

Try RICOTTA CHEESE instead of sour cream and skip the provolone for a real Italian version of Baked Ziti. Mix an egg into a pound of ricotta to make it nice and creamy, and toss with the ziti. Layer sauce first (so you don't need to butter the pan), then ziti/cheese, mozzarella, sprinkle with parm and a little dried oregano or basil, then repeat layers. For a really nice look, slice a brick of mozzarella for the top layer instead of using the shredded kind. This is SO MUCH BETTER than the sour cream version!

A new addition to our rotation.  Delicious!  I made it pretty much as written.  I changed the layering as most of the reviewers have suggested.  So: Noodles>Sauce>Provolone>Sour Cream>Noodles>Sauce>Mozz>Sauce>Parm.  Also I just seasoned the meat with garlic powder and onion powder instead of using the chopped onion.  Use yummy, quality ingredients - I imagine it is only as good as what you put into it!  This was easy, delicious comfort food.  You won't regret making it!

text:
This wasn't bad it just was a bit too cheesy for my liking and the noodles didn't have very much of the sauce flavor to them.  Next time I'd use a different cheese than provolone or try to find shredded provolone so I can evenly distribute it and adjust the amount a bit.  The slices of provolone were just a bit too think (especially where the slices overlapped). I'll also mix the pasta with some of the sauce before putting it in the pan so the pasta has an even coating of sauce to soak up the flavor.  I might also try half ground beef and half sausage to also add more flavor to the recipe.  Overall it wasn't bad it just needs a few tweaks to meet my expectations.

text:
Made this the other night & it was delish.  Even hubby loved it.  Had enough left-over for 2 more meals for 3 people.  As someone else mentioned, it was some-what difficult to spread the sour cream, so I let it sit for a while to get to room temperature. I also layered it a little differently - the provolone would seem to be a barrier keeping the meat mix from seeping through, so I layered the ziti then the meat mix.  The only thing I would do different next time is use more than 1 lb of beef - probably close to 2 lbs..  Just my preference, I like my Ziti with lots of meat...:)

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674152.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Simple and delicious!  I hate making lasagna, and this dish is essentially the same thing, minus the ricotta. The sour cream *really* helps this dish!  Moist and yummy, and you can't taste the sour cream if you are worried about picky eaters.

 I only made three changes:  I used 24 oz of Sweet Italian Sausage in place of the ground beef, used shredded 4 cheese Italian mix instead of sliced provolone + mozz, and added 1 teaspoon of dried red pepper flakes to the simmmering sauce for a little spicy kick.  

I slit open the Italian Sausages and broke/crumbled them as I sauteed them.  I followed the advice of others and switched the order of layering a bit so the sauce could get to the bottom layer of noodles.  I used Ragu 7 Herb Robusto for the sauce.  **Oh, and I used a larger pan than stated.  I have a 10 x 14 non stick pan and it was perfect. 

I highly recommend this recipe, which also freezes beautifully.

text:
I have never used a recipe for baked ziti before - just always did some some combination of ziti, ricotta cheese, sauce, mozzarella cheese and sometimes beef.  I made this recipe last night and I will always make it this way from now on.  The only substitution I made was to use ground turkey instead of ground beef.  My whole family agreed this was the best baked ziti I had ever made.  Can't wait to have the leftovers today!  Something about the sour cream makes this extra yummy - and as a bonus, sour cream is a lot less expensive than ricotta cheese!

text:
This is a good recipe, but it's a little saucy for me. Try reducing it to 1 1/2 jars sauce or replace 1 jar with a large can of drained diced tomatoes. I use sliced provolone on the first layer and an 8oz. bag of shredded Italian blend for the second and the topping. Sour cream works great, but ricotta would be good too. I coat the pan with olive oil, as butter can cause the pasta to stick to the bottom.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674156.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Had to make some substitutions based on what I had on hand.  Used 1/2 pound of beef not 1 pound. Used 250g (about 8 oz) of ricotta, mixed with an egg and a dash of nutmeg (per other reviewers' suggestions) instead of sour cream.  Used all provolone, no mozzarella as I was also out of that.  Layered as follows: ziti plus sauce mixed together, then provolone, then soft cheese mixture (ricotta), then more noodles, then more sauce, then sprinkled liberally with parmesan, then finished with slices of provolone. Covered pan with tin foil sprayed with cooking spray to keep it from sticking to the cheese.  I'd like to try making the recipe closer to the original next time but am satisfied with how I had to adapt it for what was available at the time. I had about a cup of noodles left over (I may have cooked the noodles a bit too long in the beginning so they expanded in size a lot).

country:

text:
Outstanding!!! This is definately a KEEPER. I cook alot & use many recipes on this site & this is the absolute BEST so far. If I could, I'd give this recipe 100 stars. Everyone in my family loved it and asked me to make it the next day. My daughter stopped after eating the first bite and couldn't stop telling me how good it was. They ate it all and was asking for more. I couldn't believe it because this recipes makes alot so make sure to use a large baking dish. I changed a few things after reading the reviews. I added 1/2 lb ground chuck & 1/2 lb Italian sausage. While frying, I added some chopped onion, 2 small cloves garlic-minced, salt & pepper. I used Meat Flavor Prego & added bay leaves & basil and let half the sauce simmer a little bit with the fried meat and simmered 1 jar alone to mix with the ziti before layering. I baked it 15 minutes covered and 15 minutes uncovered and it was not dry at all. IMPORTANT - Make sure to only cook the ziti al dente because it softens even more while baking and you don't want your ziti too soft and mushy. Another thing, I used sour cream and it made it soooo creamy. I don't think there's a person on this planet who won't love this meal. Enjoy!!!

text:
I just made this over the weekend- I followed several of the suggestions in previous reviews (layer of sauce on the bottom, layer of sauce over the ziti before the cheese goes one) these were very helpful tips. I have never added sour cream to baked ziti before so I was unsure how it would blend in by just putting it on the ziti - I decided to mix it into the sauce- this created a creamier sauce (if you prefer this type of sauce I suggest doing it but it can be a bit much with the other cheeses) Also the amount of cheese called for does not seem like a lot but it is probably perfect (I added more then it said and was much to cheesy).  It was still good and I will make it again but will stick to the recipe and not make the cheese changes next time and hopefully this post will help keep others from making them too. The one thing that I did change that I really thought made a positive difference is I did a semi homemade spaghetti sauce instead of the jar: the recipe I used is from this website "Tomato Sauce" by EICHORN- it is very simple and delicious.

I have made this 3 times in the past month to rave reviews and it's so simple and easy. I only needed a few revisions: added 1/4 cup of Philly Cooking creme cheese in the italian herb mix flavor, baked covered for 20 minutes and the last ten minutes uncovered and made sure the dish rested for at least 30-45 minutes before serving (otherwise it came out a bit soupy.) Instead of browning the meat, I just added good quality defrosted premade meatballs to the outer edges so the meat eaters were happy.

It was excellent! I followed the recipe as is except that i layered it differently, and i added basil, oregano, and garlic. I put the Ziti on the bottom, mixed it up with the sauce, and then put more sauce on the top. Everyone loved it! I served it with Garlic Bread and sprinkled some Basil over the top

text:
I thought this turned out really well and wasn't difficult to make.  I didn't like the idea of sour cream so believe it or not, I used low fat cream cheese (8 oz. block).  And yes, make sure you bake it COVERED.  I also used one jar of traditional spaghetti sauce (classico tomato and basil) and one jar of Vodka sauce - that gave it a rich flavoring that I really enjoyed.  I prepared this Sunday meal for my husband and I and we had plenty of leftovers for the week.  I will definitely make this again.

icet1030

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674169.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a tasty and easy recipe for the entire family.  My husband hates lasagna (after working at an Italian restaurant and getting all you can eat lasagna during his shifts- he is burnt out), but he loved this.  I love ricotta, and was hesitant not to use it in the recipe, but the sour cream was delicious!  As suggested by some other readers- my layers were: sauce, ziti, sauce, provolone, sour cream, ziti, sauce and then mozzarella.  I also added lots of garlic to the meat (I used Italian sausage).  Make sure to get a good spaghetti sauce- because there is a lot of it in this meal. Even if you don't have to, I would recommend making the dish the night before and letting it sit overnight.  I thought the leftovers were even better than when we served it the first time.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this easy recipe for a party and it was a huge hit! I recommend what others have done, and that's to stir up the bottom layer with the sauce so that the noodles are integrated in the sauce.  Also make sure you cover it with tin foil.  You can make this ahead and put it in the fridge until you are ready to make it in the oven - just be aware that if the foil touches the cheese that the foil will rip it right off the top!! So make a "tent" of foil over the top of the pan so that the foil isn't lying directly on top of your ziti!  I used fake meat for a vegetarian spin.  Boca crumbles work fantastic as well as the fake meatballs all mashed up :)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for Christmas Eve and took it to work as a suprise for the evening and night shifts.  It got raves, but made some changes: .5-.75 pound dry ziti (cooked 1-2 minutes less than package directions for al dente), 1 pound lean beef, .5 pound loose sausage, onion powder and garlic salt to browning, meat, Ragu Italian sausage and cheese spag. sauce, Italian blend cheese instead of provolone (24 cups shredded), .75 cup of sour cream, .75 cup cottage cheese, .5 cup parmesan cheese (mixed with sc and cc and 1 beaten egg), mixed sauce and meat with pasta before layering, and baked as directed.  I'm sure this recipe is wonderful as written, but I always make a change :)

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2010-09-24T19:06:56.27
helpfulCount:
2
userID:
1352547
Display Name:
melinda leigh
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
7
favoritesCount:
93
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/7155252.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I definitely seasoned the meat--how could you not?  I added approx.4-5 cloves of garlic, one FULL sauteed ONION, Lawrey's Seasoned Salt, salt & pepper to taste, dash of Italian Seasoning, dash of garlic salt, dash of "Seven Seasons" seasoning from Whole Foods, and Lea & Perrins while cooking.     Once the meat was done, I added the sourcream to the skillet (best to eye-ball how much) and then the Ragu spaghetti sauce.  I layered it as follows: Bottom has a light layer of meat sauce, then add some noodles, then some cheese, then meat again, lastly a light layer of noodles one more time, meat (if any left) & blended cheese on top. I baked it with the lid on top then uncovered it and baked it for an additional 10-15 or so to lightly brown the top.  I also sprinkled a Parmesan-Romano cheese blend on the very top before serving.  Awesome.  Note: I used the measurements for "4 servings" (which feeds at least 6 or 4 several times). I buy 1-1.5 lbs of 15% ground beef; 1 10 oz. traditional Ragu Sauce, and 2-six oz. packages of cheese--usually mozzarella & a sharper blended pack).

text:
I love this recipe!  I've been making it for years!  The only things I do different is that I cover with foil (as others suggested) and I mix the sauce with the noodles so that it's distributed evenly.  Like some other reviewer said, otherwise the provolone seems like a barrier and doesn't let the bottom layer of noodles get much sauce.

text:
This dish was delicious!! I made a few adjustments:    I used whole wheat penne. I used one 15 ounce container of part-skim ricotta and 1/2 cup of sour cream.     I'm vegetarian so I made homemade sauce with garlic, basil, roasted red pepper, and onion.     I layered sauce and pasta at the bottom. Topped with provolone. Topped with ricotta/sour cream mixture. More sauce, pasta, more provolone, parm cheese. Then I covered, cooked for 30 minutes at 350. Then uncovered and broiled for about 5 minutes to make the top nice and brown and crispy.     Delicious!

userID:
1032812
Display Name:
Michelle Roth-Kiva
isPro:

98

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2689406.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Pretty good! My fiance came back from a business trip to Orlando on Sunday. I wanted to surprise him with a hearty welcome home meal. This was just it! I pretty much followed Colleen's directions to the letter except for one major and a couple of minor changes. Neither my fiance or I care for sour cream in Italian dishes (he doesn't like the stuff at all). I couldn't substitute ricotta because he won't eat that either. I had some French onion dip in the fridge that needed using up soooo I tried it and... viola! - an instant (and tasty!) substitute. My "minor" changes were substituting hot Italian sausage for beef (on sale and quite a bit cheaper than ground beef to boot) and changing up the layering / baking steps. To ensure that my pasta would remain moist, I mixed it with my meat sauce. I then layered everything between two 8 x 8 inch pans (saved one for later this week) as follows: pasta/sauce, provolone, dip, pasta/sauce and mozza (slices) / Romano-Parm blend cheese. I baked one casserole, covered, for 30 minutes, then broiled, uncovered, on HIGH for a few minutes to get the ooey, gooey, 'crunchy around the edges' cheese effect (mmmmmm....) :) Note: To prevent any cheese from sticking to your foil, gently spritz with cooking spray. Served with garlic bread, this was a very filling meal, certainly MUCH better than SETHALLEN's recipe (which made it into the "Favorites" cookbook and I'm not sure why...). I didn't even have room for dessert! Thanks for sharing. :-)

text:
My husband LOVES baked ziti- When I showed him the recipe he seemed a little skeptical about the sour cream. I used Ragu Tradional Old World Style sauce NO MEAT but I did sautee the onion and garlic in EVOO first before adding the sauce and I added about 2 TBS smart balance to the sauce as well.-(Helps to reduce the acidity of the sauce and takes the flavor to another level) I followed the advice of other reviews and mixed the sour cream with the noodles and MY HUSBAND LOVED IT. He said it was the BEST ZITI HE EVER HAD. (He is a wonderful cook himself)  DONT BE SCARED TO USE THE SOUR CREAM- its what makes this recipe truly AMAZING!! Try it - you will not regret it!

userID:
4061262
Display Name:
JamieLea
isPro:
False
followersCount:

3

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have to admit, I never made this recipe exactly as written.  I took the advice of a couple of the other reviewers and it turned out really good...definitely a keeper recipe!  Here are the changes I made and the specific brand names we prefer...  We love the Newman's Own Cabernet Marinara sauce and Sargento brand cheeses so that's what I used.  Also, we like our dishes nice and cheesy so I used more than what the recipe called for and I decreased the onion because my husband only likes subtle onion in his food.  I mixed the sauce and pasta together before putting it in the baking dish.  I layered in this order: 1/2 the pasta & sauce mixture, 8 oz of sliced provolone (instead of 6 oz), the sour cream, the other 1/2 of the pasta & sauce mixture, 4 cups of shredded mozzarella & provolone (instead of 6 oz).  I used a baking dish that was deeper than a regular Pyrex dish so all the pasta would fit.  I baked it covered with foil for 20 minutes so it wouldn't dry out and then uncovered for an additional 10 minutes because I like the cheese to get a little brown.  It turned out moist and delicious.  I served it with Ceasar salad and garlic bread I made out of leftover hot dog buns.  My guests gobbled it up and everyone had seconds (some thirds).  Everyone loved it.  This is definitely a keeper recipe.

text:
This was so good! I changed it a bit based on other reviews on another ziti recipe which mixed the pasta with the sour cream instead of having sour cream as its own layer to avoid drying out the noodles. It was an excellent modification! I also added 5 cloves of garlic, I used ground turkey and one italian sausage instead of beef. I used a cheddar mozzarella mix with the provolone. I add chili pepper flakes and italian seasoning to my sauce, and fresh basil towards the end of simmering. My layers were sloppy but tasted great so who cares! I covered for 25 minutes, uncovered for 5 and a couple minutes on broil - sprinkled the top with some fresh basil when it came out of the oven. YUM.

text:
Although I did not follow the recipe as it is shown.  I made a ricotta mixture, instead of using sour cream. I mixed together ricotta, with some mozzarella, basil, oregano and 1 beaten egg.  Then I layered it, noodles, meat, ricotta mix, shredded mozzarella, and continued until I ran out, making sure to top it with mozzarella.  Then I cooked this UNCOVERED, however I made sure to put a cookie sheet on the oven rack below it, which was a wise choice since it did dribble over a little. (I loaded the casserole dish right to the rim). Anyway, the end result was fantastic. It tasted like a cross between lasagna and ziti - and I will definitely be using this recipe again!

text:
I had made this dish three times already and had tried out both the original provolone & sour cream and the suggestion of using ricotta & egg instead. At my house, we definitely prefer the ricotta & egg over the creamer flavor of the original ingredients. Here are some simple changes that I'd recommend to make this recipe even better:  1) Use Italian sausage meat instead of ground beef for additional flavor. Heck, try the Italian TURKEY sausage meat as a healthier option. There's plenty of cheese and sauce in this recipe to make up for the lost fat by choosing this leaner protein source.  2) For additional flavor while sneaking in those veggies, add 2+ cloves of garlic and 1 pound of sliced mushroom while browning the onion and meat. After adding the jars of spaghetti sauce, add 2 tsp each of dried oregano and basil for additional seasoning.  3) Like I've said above, I'd recommend using 1 pound of ricotta mixed with 1 egg instead of the provolone & sour cream.  4) Since this recipe reminded me of my favorite lasagna dish, I've decided to add 10oz of thawed, drained frozen chopped spinach to the mix. Here's how I layer the dish: pour some sauce to the bottom of the dish first to prevent the ziti from sticking to the dish, ziti, meat sauce, ricotta & egg, mozarella, spinach (drained well!), ziti, meat sauce, ricotta & egg, mozarella, and Parmesan cheese to finish off.  5) Definitely cover this dish with foil for the first 25 min. Then uncover and broil for the last 5 min to bro

text:
Delicious! 

For this dish I used Bertolli Tomato and Basil sauce and made several modifications based on previous posts. I added a tablespoon of garlic and one and a half cups of mushrooms while sautéing the onions, and I mixed a teaspoon each of garlic powder and oregano into the sour cream before spreading onto the provolone layer. Being a vegetarian I also used one 12 oz package of Morningstar Farms Griller's crumble in place of the ground beef. 

Lot's of flavor here I assure you. This will replace my old ziti recipe as the new standard. Thanks for the recipe and the modification suggestions.

text:
Family (of 4) really liked this - even my hubby who doesn't care for pasta commented that it was good.  My 14 yr old son had three helpings, and hubby had two!  I made very few/minor changes: used mild Italian sausage instead of ground beef (make sure you break up the sausage for even mix!), used mostaccioli instead of Ziti, and used sliced mozzarella instead of shredded.  Sprayed casserole dish with olive oil, and it worked perfectly for clean up.  Also, covered first 20 minutes, then uncovered last five (didn't bake the entire 30 minutes) and let "rest" for an additional five.  Delightful as is.  Might try adding minced garlic when browning next time to see if that's even better.  Might also try adding Italian seasonings for same reason.  Either way, this is a keeper.  Served with plain French bread and "Roasted Garlic Cauliflower" from this site.  ---  Btw, I almost never measure anything, so cheeses and sauce may have been more or they may have been less.  I eyeball everything!

text:
Incredible! Although this received so many great reviews, I was hesitant to make a pasta dish with sour cream and provolone. I followed the recipe exactly and am glad I did.  My family gulped this down.  Husband and both boys had seconds instantly.  The flavors blend themselves incredibly.  There is something magical about this combination, because every bite is creamy/cheesy but not in an overkill kind of way.  It is just pleasant.  Bite after bite after bite.  The portion is gigantic, but this was one dish the family gladly ate for leftovers.  I am making it for our family day-after-Christmas gathering.  This recipe is quick and easy to make.  DEFINITELY use the reader tip to put the sour cream in a baggie and pipe it on so it's even.  It was hard to spread the sour cream on top of sliced provolone on top of pasta, but it still turned out great.  Thank you for sharing such an awesome recipe.

text:
This was to die for!! The provolone and sour cream make it so rich and creamy. My hubby said he like this better then my stuffed shells ..and he really LOVES my stuffed shells. I blended the sour cream with about a cup of cottage cheese in the blender. WAAAY better then using ricotta. I also added lots of fresh mushrooms, garlic and onion while cooking the beef. Use a good quality sauce! ~ Makes all the differance. And .. I used rotini pasta because ...well because I just like rotini! Mixed the beef and sauce in well with the pasta between layers. Next time im going to leave out the beef and serve with Garlic Chicken from this site. =)Deserves every one of these 5 star reviews!! Thanks =D ***UPDATE*** This time added crumbled italian sausage instead of ground beef and added canned spinach (1/2 the can) to the sour cream/ cottage cheese mixture.  Soooo yum! You can make many varaitions with this recipe =D

text:
Everyone loved this one. I will make this many more times. Upon reading some of the other reviews, I changed two things. First I used quite a bit more of all three cheeses (I don't believe we would have liked it if we had used the called-for amounts). I also stirred together the pasta and sauce and layered it sauce/pasta, Parmesan, provalone, sour cream, sauce/pasta, Parmesan, and then ended with mozzarella.

text:
Three words: Quick, Easy, Tasty. I thought this was a very tasty and easy recipe. I gave it a trial run last night as I wanted to use it for my mother's 94th birthday party. Based on reviewer comments, I added salt, minced garlic, basil and oregano (all to taste). I layered 1/2 the ziti,sauce mix and cheese and used 1 cup sour cream. I think I'll try Ricotta cheese next time or 1/2 sour cream and 1/2 ricotta. I really like ricotta but the sour cream was also good. I used Bertolli olive oil and garlic sauce. I didn't think I'd like the sour cream, but you couldn't tell. This is a keeper and a good party or buffet dish.

My family LOVES this recipe. The sour cream mixes with the provolone layer to produce a lasagne-like dish. Modifications-I make the sauce with ground turkey, and I layer as follows: ziti, sauce, provolone, sour cream, ziti, sauce, provolone, sour cream, shredded 6-cheese italian blend. I bake uncovered because we love the crunchy top layer of cheese. Super easy to make!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very tasty!  If you can't find ziti - any [tube] shaped pasta will work fine, I used mostaccioli.  I decided to make this without meat (but still sauteed onion with some garlic then added the pasta sauce) and it was superb without it!  This is essentially a lasagna casserole.   I used sour cream - however, you can use any combination of sour cream, ricotta, cottage cheese, or plain yogurt (I typically use yogurt and ricotta for my lasagna because it's healthier and lower in fat).  I added a generous 1/2 cup grated parmesan to the sour cream and a couple tablespoons of freshly chopped parsley.  I doubled the amount of mozzarella!  Since my daughters don't care for spicy - I sprinkled crushed red peppers afterwards on the adults servings... it was very very good!  This recipe makes a LOT - excellent for leftovers.  Otherwise, you can prepare two separate dishes; bake one and freeze the other for another occasion!

userID:
2341179
Display Name:
Moosehead
isPro:

followersCount:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/91294.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
i wasn't able to take a photo of my ziti but i think ya'll know how a baked ziti looks like anyway.

i pretty much followed the original recipe except that i added a layer of meat sauce right on top of the bottom layer of ziti then the layer of provolone. that was a recommendation from other reviewers. i think it works.

this recipe is pretty fail proof. i think it would have tasted better if i had used a diff. spaghetti sauce. i bought two glasses of organic trader joes spaghetti sauces. each jar is about 26 oz. and was the perfect amount for 8 servings. the baked ziti pasta is perfect b/c it is tougher than other kinds of pasta. it holds up well even after a couple days. the ziti actually tastes better after a day or two. i think the sauce just fuses into the pasta. i also added about 4 cloves of minced garlic to the meat. it just gave it much more flavor.

i'm big spicy food so i ended up pouring tobasco sauce all over the top. next time, i would add some crushed red pepper flakes into the meat sauce and maybe even  a cup of white wine when it simmers. it was missing something in the end so i think by adding these two ingredients will help a lot. 

the secret to this recipe is def. the sour cream. i would add more of it or just add a dollop on top after it's baked. it gives it that sour tangy taste.

text:
ABSOLUTE BEST ZITI RECIPE!  It does make alot.  Like others , I put in 2 pans & freeze one.  I have made this many times.  I also mix together sour cream, sauce & pasta before layering.  When I do make it in 1 pan it has always been a hit at sports award dinners & pot lucks.  I have been asked for this recipe many a time.  When making into 2 trays, you need more cheese.  I layer 6 slices prov. cheese per tray.  Also, I can't be bothered to measure out 1 1/2  cups sour cream so I just use a 16 oz. container.  IT'S GREAT!

text:
The recipe always turns out great for me (and I cook uncovered unlike all of the people with negative responses on here). Maybe mine is soupier, or the way I layer the top makes a difference on dryness?? I don't know, all I do know is it has never turned out bad and I always get positive comments when I make it from others!

Note: Instead of adding two jars of spaghetti sauce, I don't even pay attention to how big of cans I use, I just make my normal spaghetti recipe with either turkey meat or sausage depending on what I have in the freezer at the time and add it when I'm layering.

The sour cream is ingenious! I look to this site for inspiration for new meals or ideas to jazz up basic recipes-then use what I have on hand. The sour cream was a 5-star addtion to a regular Ziti that I make using italian sausage, baby bella mushrooms, any pasta shape I have, mozzarella, and freshly grated parm. text:
YUMMY...complete comfort food!  I ended up cutting this recipe in half as I was just making for hubby and our 5 and 3 year old boys (the 5 month old can't eat it yet!!). Covered and baked for about 35 mins and then uncovered for about 10.  Did not use a 9 x 13, but used a 2.5Q round dish.  Turned out great!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great base recipe.  I actually originally tried it a year ago but not having sour cream on hand, had omitted that and was not wowed.  I tweaked the recipe and created a version that I preferred but that still did not have the sour cream.  After seeing it on a Top 20 list and reading the reviews, I thought I'd try it using the sour cream.  That was definitely the key - it adds a great zip to the flavours.  I can now say I am wowed.  Both my picky Hubby AND my finicky 2 1/2 year old gobbled it up.  The version I made though used my original alterations WITH the addition of the sour cream.  I added a few spices to the ground beef mixture - 3 tsp minced garlic, 1 tsp ground black pepper, 1/4 cup fresh chopped parsley, 2 tsp dried basil, 1/2 tsp grilled steak seasoning and 1 tsp mixed vegetable seasoning.  I also use double the mozzarella instead of provolone, grated marble cheese instead of parmesan and 26 oz tomato sauce and 13 oz spaghetti sauce (rather than 2 jars spag).  The only thing I would change the next time, would be to use light sour cream...the richness made me worry about calories!!

I was planning on making lasagna when I realized I had no lasagna noodles. I had all ingredients on hand and this was Perfect! I will probably make this instead of lasagna going forward, it is an easy and delicious alternative. Mix sauce with noodles BEFORE the layering process. Another tip is to use more sauce then called for. Naturally some of it will dry up even if it is covered. I wasn't sure about the sour cream, but it was delicious, it really made the cheese part of the dish creamy and cheesy. I added ricotta cheese AND fresh baby bella mushrooms. YUMMO!

text:
Made several modifications: (1)  Sauteed some minced garlic with the onions (2)  Added italian seasoning, salt, pepper, parmesan cheese to red sauce mixture (3) like alot of the other reviewers, changed the layer orders.  (1/2 ziti, sauce, sour cream mixture, provolone, repeat)  (4)  To me, baked ziti just isn't baked ziti without ricotta cheese.  So I mixed  in half ricotta and half sour cream.  In the end,  1.5 cups sour cream/cheese was not nearly enough for this dish.  Double that however, and you've got a great baked ziti dish!

text:
I made this ziti for a few of my friends last night for a hang-out/dinner night and it was a HUGE success.  I did follow the suggestions of other users and mix some of the sauce in with the ziti noodles before I put them in the pan (I actually poured about 1/3 of one of the jars of sauce into the pot after I drained the noodles - it just made life easier), and it turned out perfectly.  The recipe did almost over-fill my 9x13, so I put a cookie sheet underneath it when I placed it in the oven so that I didn't have a huge mess to clean later.  I probably will put some in another separate pan the next time I make it so that it doesn't overflow.  But other than that, it was an amazing recipe, and definitely a keeper.

None
text:
I make this often!  3 stars because I did not like this with sour cream AT ALL...normally I love sour cream on anything, it just was not the right flavor for baked ziti.  The sourness/tang of the sour cream makes it taste as if you used bad cheese (think spaghetti with sour cream in it) so I use ricotta instead and sometimes I use mild Italian sausage for the beef.  The first 5 or 6 times I mixed the pasta with sauce first and then layered, topping off with mozzerella and letting it get golden brown on top, but then I decided to make it the way it states in the recipe and I actually like it a lot better!  So from now on I will layer it the way the recipe states.  Thanks for the great recipe!

text:
My daughter gave this 3 stars, but everyone else in the family gave it 4 stars. This is a very good, but very rich, dish.  The ingredients almost overflowed in my 9x13 inch pyrex baking dish, so I placed it on a foil lined cookie sheet to catch the "overflow" in the oven. I did as others suggested and covered while it cooked and put the sauce on the ziti before the cheese. This is an easy dish, but it took me longer than 20 minutes in prep time. I will do this one again.

Like most everyone, I was tentative about using the sour cream. This is a fantastic recipe!  My family loved loved loved it!  I have made it 4 more times and it turns out the same every time.  I layer it like the recipe calls for the only thing I did differently was put some of the sauce on the bottom of the pan. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My hubby loves Italian food and wanted me to make baked ziti.  I found this recipe and I am so glad I did!  I used half ground beef and half hot Italian sausage, two jars of the Bertolli mushroom and garlic sauce, Sargento 6 cheese Italian shredded cheese, and added a few extra spices and fresh garlic.  Per the suggestion of other reviewers, I mixed the pasta with the meat sauce before spreading it in the pan.  This makes way too much for a 9x13 dish.  I used a deep 4 quart baking dish.  I baked the ziti for 40 minutes and then took the foil off and baked it for another five minutes or so.  I know the sour cream sounds a little different, but don't leave it out.  It made the ziti so creamy.  Also, I would recommend using regular sour cream, not low fat.  This is a very rich dish and can't be a regular week day dinner, but will definitely go into the recipe book.  I am already looking forward to making it for my in laws.

This is fantastic! I've made this many times for the family, as well as having taken it to numerous potlucks..never a disappointment. This recipe allows for liberal additions of whatever one most enjoys. Extra cheese? Go for it. Additional sauce? No problem. The only change I make is to omit the ground beef and replace it with ground Italian sausage. Paired with a nice ceasar and some crusty italian bread, this makes for a very happy belly indeed.

text:
Very good!   The only modification I made was to add one can of sauce to the pasta before layering.  

My husband and daughter were impressed with this dish and had seconds.  This is a great recipe to prepare ahead of time and then pop in the oven right before dinnertime.  I served this with salad, Focaccio bread, and a bottle of red wine for the adults.

I think the secret to this recipe is the sauce -- a bland sauce will make it mediocre at best.  The other ingredients don't add much taste.

Ok, I gave this a whirl to see what sour cream (instead of ricotta) tastes like in baked ziti.  Not only is it creamier and less grainy, it also tastes like ricotta!  I subbed ground turkey for the beef, used low fat cheeses/sour cream and my own sauce with spectacular results.  Makes A LOT, too; I halved the recipe to 4 servings and there is still enough leftover for 2 hearty portions.  This has become a new family favorite.  Thanks!

text:
If I could give it six stars, I would.  Oh my gosh!  I happened upon this recipe one day while browsing around the allstar recipes and saved this one to my box.  So glad I did.  It was different than my regular baked ziti casserole and I thought I would give it whirl.  Yummy, yummy, yummy.  All four kids loved it, hubby had 3 helpings and I went back for seconds myself!  Made exactly as stated except for throwing in a couple of cloves of garlic with the meat (couldn't help myself!) and used 8oz. of mozarella instead of 6oz since that is how my grocery store sells it.  We will trash our old ziti recipe and switch to this one.  At first, I thought the sour cream would be a wierd ingredient, but it added just the right kick.  This will become a staple at our house.  And the best part?  Easy, easy, easy and fast, fast, fast for a busy mom!

text:
This was a GREAT recipe! The sour cream was a nice new twist in the traditional flavor of baked ziti. I added some red pepper flakes and, like others, put the sauce on top of the ziti (instead of on top of the cheese) so that the ziti would be flavorful. I actually mixed the meat sauce with the ziti because I refrigerated it overnight before baking it the next day, and wanted the ziti to be lathered in the sauce rather than stick to each other. Thanks for the recipe!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good, easy-to-prepare recipe. This should serve 8 good appetites (w/bread - or garlic bread - and a salad). Very creamy, great flavor. I used sliced mozzarella instead of shredded (I picked up the sliced provolone at the deli counter, so why not kill two birds...?). There was no discernible difference, and you may actually save some $$$ too. Leftovers weren't as tasty as it was fresh, but when it was fresh.....yum. Quick, delicious meal that tasted like the local Italian place down the corner. Worth it! (Don't forget to grease the pan, and undercook the ziti just a bit. It will continue cooking when you bake it to make it perfectly al dente). Thanks, Colleen!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
We LOVE this recipe!  
I used hot Italian sausage instead of ground beef and added garlic to the onion.   
I used Ragu's Chunky Tomato, Garlic and Onion spaghetti sauce.  I prefer it's sweeter taste to the other saltier sauces.  
I also loved the idea of using a pasta with ridges to "hold" the sauce, so I used mostaccioli pasta.  
No matter how many times I've tried Ricotta, I end up with the same opinion...It's just not for me.  I do, however, love the sour cream.  Thanks for making it a part of your recipe Colleen.
Reading the reviews, I decided to layer the dish with pasta, meat sauce, provolone, sour cream, pasta, mozzarella, meat sauce, and Parmesan...and cover with aluminum foil.
BTW, we did try it following the original recipe, but prefer the changes made because it suits our family's tastes better.
Thanks for sharing Colleen!

text:
Loved this! Heres the changes I made. I sauteed onions and garlic with olive oil and then added 1 pound ground turkey. After I added the sauce and simmered it, I let it cool and added the sour cream right into the sauce mixture. It turned it into almost a pink vodka looking sauce. I thought this was was easier then trying to spread the sour cream on a layer and it worked wonderfully! My whole family raves about this recipe! Excellent!

Pretty good, however... I modified the recipe to be lower calorie and fat.  The regular recipe is 696cal per serving!  So, I only used 1 cup of sour cream and I used the light version.  I only used 1/2 lb. of extra lean ground beef instead of a full pound.  The mozzerella I used was part-skim instead of regular.  Pretty darned good! I dont know how much lower the calories are but everything helps.  Good recipe.

text:
Excellent as is and so easy!  Don't change anything until you try it as written first.  To address some of the other reviewers- don't use more provolone than called for and the sauce WILL get to the bottom layer.  Also, don't worry if you couldn't fit all the ingredients in and had to leave some sauce out- I thought it was too saucy anyway.  I'm going to reduce the amount of sauce next time.

text:
This turned out very well.  We followed some of the other suggestions here and combined some ricotta with the sour cream.  The sour cream gave just the right amount of tanginess without being overbearing.  My only suggestion for improving this recipe would be to put some of the sauce in first, or at least over the noodles before the provolone and cheese mixture so that it can disperse throughout the noodles.  Otherwise, you end up with a very full pan at the end (we couldn't fit all of the sauce into the pan).

I made this, but took the advice of others and used 1/2 sour cream (light) and 1/2 ricotta cheese.  My husband and daughter loved it -- I thought it was pretty good, but not my favorite.  It was a bit too bland for me, and I got a little tired of the sour cream taste (strange, since I love sour cream!).  Next time I think I'll make it with a spicier sauce and use a little less of the sour cream/cheese mixture.  It, also, made a lot -- 9x13 baking dish was filled!
Review:
Rating:
4
dateLastModified:

text:
I made this yesterday with great results.  I didn't have any ziti pasta left so I used the large (not jumbo) shells in their place. Also, I only used mozzerella cheese = 4oz per layer. Very good and easy!! The sour cream is the trick to keeping the overall recipe "creamy."  We ate until we were stuffed and there were still leftovers.  But, even the leftovers were tasty too. Would make this tasty ziti rendition again! Thanks Colleen!

This was easy, but tasted like I spent hours on it!  I only had mozzerella cheese and it was still delicious.  Definitely a keeper.

To those who say this was too dry, you had to have done something wrong.  I've made this literally dozens of times and it is amazing every time.  The recipe calls for TWO-26 oz. jars of spaghetti sauce.  My guess is these folks are only using one and in that case it would be dry.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
When I saw all the reviews I knew this was the one to try, this is a great recipe! I used 1lb of Safeway mild Italian sausage casing removed and browned mixed with 1 jar of Barilla, Green and Black Olive Sauce, left out the onion(family preference) and covered with foil during baking. The flavor of the olives, tomatoes, capers, cheese, and sour cream were a delightful change from regular pasta. My family had seconds and thirds and I still had lots of leftovers, enough for another meal. If you don't have Ziti(I can't find it in my local grocery) try this with Rigatoni. I think one jars of sauce is enough but you will have to cover so it doesn't dry out. This is good leftover,  the kids are eating it cold out of the refrigerator.

text:
I changed this recipe a little.  I used a combination of very lean ground beef and lean ground pork.  After frying that, I drained and rinsed it under cool water to get rid of some of the fat.  When making the first layer, I added grated mozzarella cheese on top of the layer of provolone cheese, but I forgot the sour cream!  When it was done, I added the sour cream (I used fat-free)on top of everything on individual plates, and it still turned out very well!  If I can mess this up this badly and it still is delicious, it surely is a keeper.

text:
This is a delicous recipe for ziti.  One of the better ones I've found, anywhere.  I add a little garlic to it though.  Its easy to work with too.  You can add or omit whatever you like.  The first time I made it, I thought I needed more sauce.  So, the second time - I added a can of sauce to the recipe.  It came out wonderful.  This is a fantastic, cheesy, wonderful tasting ziti! Note: I was amazed that the sour cream looked just like ricotta cheese once cooked!

text:
This is a really great recipe.  It is very easy to prepare, with ingredients you are likely to have lying around anyway.  You need a deep pan or at least a 9x13" casserole in order to fit everything into the pan.  If you spoon everything in carefully, it does all fit, even with the two jars of sauce.  I followed the recipe almost exactly - I did add a shake of garlic powder to the meat, however.  I used high quality spaghetti sauce and it was just wonderful.  10 Stars!

I loved this!  I manipulated the recipe a bit.  We have a gourmet grocery store in town and I bought some really great sausage instead of round beef.  I also used some extra spices and eye balled the amount of cheese needed.  The spaghetti sauce I used was green pepper/mushroom and garlic/onion.  The sauce will make or break this meal! I thoroughly enjoyed this and will continue to make this dish for all occassions!

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Made this for the first time tonight as I needed a fast, easy, available ingredient recipe.  Didn't have provolone slices, so used 8 oz shredded Kraft italian cheese mix in place.  Probably easier to spread the sour cream over the provolone slices.  May use ricotta cheese next time as I make lasagna once a month and I like the flavor and texture.  But recipe good with sour cream as well per my unexpected guests.  Covered it for half the time, then uncovered last half.  Would make again.  Simple. Fast. Easy. Good.  Great for larger crowd or leftovers as needed.

text:
I wanted to comment so I could clarify a few things. When ever i make a receipe i prefer to follow it to the letter the first time around rather then making adjustments before I have tasted it.  I read many comments of people being up in arms about the sour cream/provolone combo. I can tell you it is very good. I loved it instead of ricota cheese because if i wanted to make a lasagna i would have.  It has great flavor and really it ends up with a ricotta cheese like consistancy anyway. Give it a taste and make it as instructed and see for your␀self before your edits. 
I did use aluminum to cover it which I won't do next time as it was quiet mosit and I had a bit of liquid at the bottom when i was done. 
Flowed to the letter the receipe is amazing. 
One thing I would note is this receipe does a good job of highlighting the pasta to that effect I would say this a good recipe for better noodles. I used cheap zitti so next time im gonna try some higher end pasta. And maybe sharp provolone. 
Your flavor and variety will be in your sauce. Ground beef and a well seasoned sauce is good. Subbing Italian  sausage for the ground beef is a real easy way to up the complexity and flavor of this dish.  
I made it a second time and I mixed the sauce and noodle layers because of the comments I read. This, in my opinion is unnesacerry and runs the risk of changing they way ingredients interact. Again I advise trying this receipe one time by following it to the later before making adjustments.

text:
I made this for my grandson's 3rd birthday family party this past weekend.  Everyone raved about it.  My grandson couldn't get enough.  He ended up having 3 helpings.  I made it without the meat because it is Lent and most of the people there were Catholic.  I did the assembly a bit different.  I mixed the ziti, sauce, sour cream and mozzerella in a large bowl.  Then I put half the mixture in the baking pan and put 6 slices of provolone and some parmesan cheese.  I then put the rest of the ziti mixture on top and topped it with mozzerella.  It is much easier that way and all of the ziti is covered with the sauce mixture.  I also used the Kraft mozzerella with the cream cheese in it.  It melts so nicely.   This is going in my permanent collection.

text:
we really love this recipe, and by we, I mean four of the six people in my house. I was a bit hesitant to use sour cream, but I'm not a big ricotta fan, so I figured we'd give it a go. Super easy to make and most of the house loves it, so thats a win in my book. The only change I make is making it ahead of time and pop it into fridge until ready to cook, and split it into two 8x8 pans. Be aware that this makes a lot of food, so your baking dish will be heaping, not level. Also make sure you use a spagetti sauce that has a lot of flavor, since thats were most of the taste of this dish will come from.

userID:
1209213
Display Name:
shwilson
isPro:

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
Continuation of previous review. Apparently the review will not format paragraphs. So, important points: 1) integral to the success of this recipe is to cook the ziti until just barely al dente. That allows it to cook the rest of the way in the oven with the ziti remaining firm. 2) DO NOT use ricotta. I think the provolone/sour cream mixture is inspired. If the texture bothers you, use provolone and 4% cottage cheese.  Today I used a mixture of sour cream and cottage cheese as I had cottage cheese that was reaching its expiration date. 3) I make my own sauce, basically using the recipe for the sauce used in worlds best lasagna.....a recipe on this site. I use Italian sausage and ground chuck. Today I chopped up 2 green peppers, 3 onions, minced 9 cloves of garlic. I sautéed that with the meat, chili pepper flakes, oregano, basil, etc.  I used some red wine and fennel seeds in the sauce. If I’m making several pans, I make the sauce a day ahead just to cut down on the work. 4) as far as baking it covered....it just depends on how much sauce I have in the pan. Today I did not cover it (8x8 pan) as I wanted some of the sauce to evaporate. It was perfect. But for a big pan, I’d cover it.   5) I’ve layered it all different ways...it’s always good as long as the ziti is al dente.  6) I’ve always had rave reviews for this recipe. It freezes great.  It’s worth the effort to have a nice meal waiting in the freezer.

text:
Obviously a very simple recipe, but it was well received. We substituted ziti noodles for rigatoni without problem. Like many others have said, I found the cheese on top to get very brown and nearly burnt - if you don't like it so crispy, you may want to cover the dish or add more cheese on top.

text:
Very good! I made some adjustments to mine. These included:
          Using ground Italian sausage,
           Red Cabernet Sauvignon wine,
           Garlic,
           Italian mix cheese and chedder cheese.
I cooked the Italian sausage with the onion and garlic and added salt and pepper. After adding the Tony Newman's sockarooni sauce I added two cap fulls of Cabernet Sauvignon red wine. Think I'll do another cap full next time. I let it simmer for the 15 min then stirred in some sour cream. I didn't measure it. Just did to taste. Layered it and I had not problem fitting it all into a 9x13 pan, but I did take time to put the noodles in line. Layered it, covered to bake and was yummy!

text:
2/18/17: This was my first time making baked ziti.  I used 2 jars of Newman's tomato and basil (24 oz each) and added a small jar of spaghetti sauce (which wasn't really needed).  I did 1# pound beef and half a tube of italian sausage.  I added some garlic. I combined 3/4 cup sour cream and 3/4 cup ricotta.  I used the entire 8 oz package of provolone slices and the entire 8 oz package of shredded mozzarella.  Combine the meat and pasta. I used a 9x12 disposable pan and an 8x8 glass dish but should have stuck with a 9x13 size.  let it rest 10 minutes before cutting.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This is a winning recipe that I will definitely be making often at my house! I made a few changes- First, I used penne pasta instead of ziti (I couldn't find ziti at the store). I am a huge fan of eggplant, so I baked a large eggplant in the oven for an hour, and then diced it and added it to my meat mixture. The eggplant added a lot of flavor and texture. Yum! Also, I did the layering a little differently; On the bottom layer I mixed the pasta with my meat mixture, just to make sure that the pasta didn't dry out. I then spread on a layer of sour cream, then  covered with sliced provolone and shredded mozzarella. Then for the top layer I spread on the pasta, the remaining meat mixture and topped with shredded mozzarella  and shredded three-cheese mix. It turned out amazing!!!

text:
This recipe was a hit! My husband, 9 year old daughter, & my husbands coworkers raved about this!! I followed the recipe, with only a few minor changes. I used tomato & basil pasta sauce (I used a few ounces more than the recipe called for). I added a tsp of sugar, garlic powder & red pepper flakes to the sauce. I also mixed the cooked noodles with the sauce, as recommended by other reviewers. I used more cheese than called for because we LOVE cheese. I considered substituting ricotta for the sour cream & provolone, but after trying it, I'm so happy that I didn't. The sour cream adds moisture & the provolone gave this dish an amazing flavor. I covered & baked for 25 minutes. It was phenomenal!!

I have made this recipe for years now as my go-to "feed an army" meal. I'm about to make it again this weekend for our Labor Day family reunion "up north." text:
This recipe needed some changes. Definitely swap the sour cream for ricotta! I also ditched the provolone in favor of thick slices of mozzarella--it added an excellent touch. I also changed this to be vegetarian and swapped the meat for Crimini mushrooms browned and simmered in black truffle oil with onions. I use one can of vodka pasta sauce and one can of garlic and herb pasta sauce. I season with Herbs de Provence and garlic. The result? A much more authentic, creamy, fulfilling dish that is a huuuuuge hit for any dinner party! People go nuts for the notes of truffle and herb seasoning. Even my friends who say they don't like mushrooms love this dish. Easy and quick to make!

Excellent starting point. I used italian sausage instead of ground beef, which I browned with the onion and two cloves of garlic. I used one jar of spaghetti sauce and one 15 ounce can of diced tomatoes. I Added extra italian seasoning, a dash of crushed red pepper, a handful of sliced mushrooms and red bell pepper. I mixed the 1 1/2 cups of sour cream withan equal amount of ricotta.  Finally, instead of making the pasta and sauce as separate layers, I mixed the two together. Then I layered pasta/sauce, then ricotta, then mozzarella, then provolone. Repeated the layers and topped with parmesan. My family LOVED it. It's even better the second day!

text:
I love this recipe!!!!! I have made it 3 times since I found it, and each time it tasted even better!!! I usually make a romaine salad and asparagus. A few tips are instead of sour cream, use ricotta cheese. This is just if you want the more Italian version.  Also, if you want it to be more Italian, then don't use the provolone cheese. You could substitute it for more mozzarella, or just pour the sauce mixture on the pasta without any cheese in between ;)  All in all this is a great baked ziti recipe!!!!!

text:
This was great. I put a thin layer of sauce in the bottom to prevent sticking and then assembled the rest as instructed. I baked it covered so it didn't dry out. It turned out great. The only change I made was to add a little chopped garlic in with the onion for extra flavor. 

If I made this again I would use half ground beef and half Italian sausage for depth of flavor. I'd also add some extra fresh or dried herbs (oregano, basil, rosemary) to the sauce and let it simmer to add another layer of flavor.

I loved this recipe.  I did make some changes. I used rotini pasta (that's what I had on hand), I used vegetables instead of meat. I sautéed onion, zucchini, and red bell pepper with some minced garlic. I used an organic spaghetti sauce. I mixed the pasta, sauce and veggtables together and put half the mixture in the pan, topped it with the provolone cheese and sour cream then topped that layer with  the rest of the pasta mixture and Added the mozzarella and Parmesan cheeses. Covered and baked for about 30 min at 325. Very easy recipe! Oh, did I mention it was delicious =)

text:
Like all recipes on this website, I read the reviews before I dive in because I always get great tips about the recipe. This one is no different. I took the advice about cutting the recipe in half. It's just the two of us....even that was a tad much, but I blame myself. When the recipe was cut in half, the measuring amounts became odd numbers so I just rounded up to the next whole number. I didn't want to waste ingredients. I also made some substitutions based on recommendations from other reviewers to make it healthier. I changed the sour cream to plain greek yogurt. One reviewer missed the ricotta cheese so I just took my measurement of the sour cream made a mixture that was 2/3 plain greek yogurt and 1/3 reduced fat ricotta cheese. I used ground turkey instead of lean ground beef. I used reduced fat provolone slices and mozzarella cheese. I took the advice of one of the reviewers and got some quality spaghetti sauce. I was too lazy to buy additional vegetables to add to the meat sauce but that is something that you can do. I used rigatoni instead of ziti and that worked perfectly.
I followed the recipe instructions in regards to how to prepare the ziti. Quite a few of the reviewers suggested to mix the meat mixture with the noodles before you layer. I did and that was perfect. I layered in corning ware and put the lid on and put it in the oven. It came out perfect. It was lasagna with rigatoni. My boyfriend had two servings. I will make this again in a heartbeat.

helpfulCount:
1
userID:
8046774
Display Name:
ginluk
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
3
favoritesCount:
60
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/733456.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this dish recently for a small dinner party I hosted.  I followed other suggestions about layering and using a bigger pan.  My dinner party guests really liked it, and were going back for seconds and third helpings!   

However, I blundered a bit so I'm sharing my experience so others won't make the same goofs!

I made it the day before, and cooked it for 15 minutes then put it in the fridge.  I figured I could stick it in the oven with another dish I was making the day of the party, and finish cooking it.  I didn't want to fully cook the dish the day before, then re-heat it because I thought it might dry it out.  So day of the party I cooked it for another 30 minutes at 350 degrees, but it wasn't long enough!  The layer of provolone never melted, which wasn't apparent until I was serving the dish and I was digging into my own portion.  

I don't know if anyone even noticed, but I was a little embarrassed!  

So, if I were to do it again, I'd probably either cook it completely the day before then reheat it, or just leave it in the oven for about 45 minutes the day of the shindig if I didn't cook it fully the day before.    I'd also use a different spaghetti sauce.  (For the record, I used sauce from Trader Joe's and I didn't care for it.  One of my guests mentioned it seemed too acidic.)
Review:
Rating:
3

2014-09-29T18:33:25.71

userID:
11202359
Display Name:
Julie Hackett
isPro:
False
followersCount:
10

0

5

105

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1731201.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I only have one word for you-AMAZING! Every single person who tried this came up to me asking for the recipe (those who knew I cooked it, that is--others thought I had it brought in from a restaurant!)
A few notes:
1. I had to omit the meat since my crowd wasn't a meat eating crowd, but I still browned the onion for about five minutes and simmered the onion with the sauce for about ten minutes in a skillet. You DEFINITELY need two jars of sauce, if you are thinking its too much--it's not.
2. I used Bertoli Tomato and Basil canned sauce.
3. I read all the reviews before cooking this and followed the recommendation to layer it a bit differently.  Instead of leaving the bottom layer of ziti "un-sauced", I mixed the bottom layer of ziti with 1/3 the sauce before then layering the provolone and the sour cream.  I then mixed the next layer of ziti with 1/3 of the sauce, followed by the mozerella mixed with the remaining 1/3 of sauce and the parmesan cheese. I covered it, baked it at 350 degrees for exactly thirty minutes, and VOILA! Instant masterpiece!!!

I am so glad that allrecipes.com gives users like me a chance to read reviews for tips and tricks---the layering was genius! I will be bringing this to work from now on. Thanks!

5

However, I believe this dish would have been much better had everything been incorporated evenly, rather than layering the ingredients.

text:
I'm always alter recipes to my liking and add or take away things. Instead of Sour Cream I used Ricotta Cheese and mixed it with a 1/2 cup of Provolone, Asiago, and Parmesan Cheese. I also used mild Italian Sausage instead of plain beef.  I used tomatoes sauce and added my own spices but I did use about 42oz of it. I also used onions and mushrooms. I mixed about 1 lb. of mozzarella cheese in my sauce after I sautéed my veggies and I also added my meat and drained the grease off. Oh almost forgot, I beat a egg then I add it to the Ricotta mixture and blend well. I know that I alter the recipe a bunch but overall it's a good recipe, I always make a dish my own.

text:
This was my first time making baked ziti and my fiancé and I loved it! However,  I did tweak it a bit. I sautéed 2 minced garlic cloves with the onion and added a pinch of parsley to the top before putting it in the oven. Although, It didn't say to cover with foil or not. I decided to cover it. I didn't have that problem with it coming out dry so I definitely recommend to cover with foil.

Display Name:
Cyndie

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674146.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this but modify the recipe above significantly. You can really ruin this as long as you have enough sauce so customize it for your family's tastes.  I sauté 1lb hamburger, 1lb ground sausage with the onion and garlic.  I use Ricotta cheese mixed w/one egg and then toss the noodles in it before adding it to the pan.  I put my sauce down first, but still spray the pan with Pam.  I add one 15oz can of tomato sauce to the jarred sauce.  I use a whole brick of Mozzarella for this.  I slice the Mozzarella and layer the slices as I make it, ending with mozzarella on top.  And yes - cover it!  Depending on how deep your pan is, will determine how long it needs to cook.  For my recipe, I need 60 minutes minimum, then I take the foil off, lower the temp to 350 deg, and bake it for another 20-30 minutes until everything is bubbling and gooey.

I boiled my pasta with 2 cubes of beef "squares of broth I cannot spell", dumped the sauce/beef/onion mixture that I added about 4 cloves of garlic to back in the pot with the drained pasta, mixed in the sour cream, and did 2 layers. The mixture, topped with provolone, mozzerella, and parm, then more pasta mixture, and the other half of the cheeses on top. baked as directed. Used 2 jars of Rinaldi sauce that was on sale. One jar was garlic and onion or something and the other was mushroom and peppers I think. Turned out amazing. Especially since I am not a ricotta cheese fan.

text:
Ok, caveat:  I'm not a big fan of ricotta cheese.  And I add sour cream quite often to my pasta dishes.  I'm not going for "authentic" Italian, here.  I'm feeding my family good food.  Having said all of that - I really liked the recipe!  I gave it 4 stars because the ground beef needed something.  I did sauté' it with onions and garlic, s&P.  I think next time (and yes there will be a next time) I'll use Italian sausage.  OH!  And the jar sauce really matters.  Use what you would use plain on pasta.  If the sauce is bland this too will be bland.  Thank you for a really  nice recipe!

text:
Love this recipes. I have made it a couple times. The sour cream gives it the special uniqueness so please do not substitute for ricotta. The only suggestions that I agree with is putting sauce on the first layer before the cheese and sour cream since the cheese does create a barrier that prevents the sauce from going to the bottom. The second is adding some Italian sausage to the mix.  Gives it a little more kick and makes it more meaty. Make sure you have guest as the 13X9 makes a lot! Great recipe!!!!

I made this last night for my family and it was very well received by my 8 yo and hubby :) Comforting and delicious!! text:
Delicious recipe!!  I especially like the use of the sour cream. I was skeptical but it was (and is because I am literally eating it right now). I made this for my 3 yr old and 2 yr old so I changed it to add veggies. I used pasta with veggies cooked in it, I mashed up some carrots and peas and added them to the sauce. My kids nor my husband could even tell there were veggies added. As a mom, that was a good feeling to have my kids actually eating veggies without forcing them. They actually asked for more!!!  I see other people put that it dried out but I did it uncovered and had plenty of sauce on top.  I think that helped it not dry out.

text:
This is my favourite pasta dish; it's the perfect combination of flavours! To make it vegetarian, I sub chopped cremini mushrooms for the ground beef and I change up the method based on a previous review - mix the sour cream with the hot drained pasta, put 1/2 in the baking dish, spread 1/2 of the sauce mix and top with 1/2 of the cheese and repeat with remaining ingredients. yum-o!

Very good, however I did alter some things. I had penne pasta, and only one jar of sauce. I didn't have provolone, so I used all mozzarella. Used mild Italian sausage instead of ground beef. I generously ground black pepper into the sauce while it simmered. Baked it in a deep dish casserole for only about 20 minutes (pasta and sauce were still hot, only the sour cream was cold) and it was perfect. Not DRIPPING with sauce, but not dry either.

This was wonderful and very easy to make!  The only change I made was, I tossed the ziti in a tiny bit of the sauce before putting in the bottom of the pan.  It seemes like it would get dried out without it. We don't like ricotta, so this recipe was PERFECT for us. The sour cream was a nice touch. I thought it was strange at first, but it turned out quite similar to ricotta but without the texture (which is what we don't like about it) Everyone loved it so we will surely be making it again at our house!

text:
I have been using this recipe for years, and haven't had a single person NOT say that it was amazing. I use ground turkey instead of beef, and an 8 ounce package of italian blend cheese (mozzarella, provolone, romano, parmesan, fontina & asiago) instead of the 6 oz mozzarella and 2 oz parmesan. I also layer differently: 1/2 ziti, 1/2 sauce, sliced provolone, sour cream, a handful of the italian cheeses, remaining ziti, remaining sauce, and remaining cheese.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This baked ziti is SO delicious! I followed everyone's advice and covered the final product before putting it in the oven, but I didn't get a crispy ziti at the end. It was moist, cheesy, and gooey in all the right places, but maybe next time I will remove the aluminum foil for the last 5 minutes of the baking time. 

I seasoned the meat with black pepper and garlic powder. After browning it with the onions and added garlic, I poured in the tomato sauce and one can of mushroom pieces. 

After the simmering was done, I directly placed the sauce on top of the first half of noodles, and then added the cheese, sour cream and so on. Following someone else's tip, I stirred the bottom layer of ziti and sauce together before I added anything else just to make sure that the sauce ran all through the noodles. 

I sprinkled fresh minced basil on top that gave an extra twang to the dish.

This recipe was easy and tasty!  My only sub was Johnsonville Italian Sausage for the ground beef, and it was more flavorful than plain ground beef.  I followed other reviewers' advice and mixed the sauce with the ziti, before creating a layer of cheese in the middle.  I covered with foil for 1/2 the baking time, and uncovered for the rest of the time.  Using purchased spaghetti sauce is a real convenience, though I'm sure home made would be much better.  This recipe filled my large casserole dish to the brim.

country:
None
text:
I am giving it five stars after some tweaks. I kept the recipe, for the most part, the same. I didn't have meat so I did just the cheese version,and I mixed the first layer of sauce with the first layer of pasta in the pan. I didn't worry about doing that with the second layer and it came out great. First, COVER THE PAN while it's in the oven. It keeps everything nice and soft. Second, 30 mins at 350 is not nearly as hot or as long as needed. This recipe makes a HUGE helping. Either, bump the oven temp up and keep it at 30 minutes, or keep at 350 and bake for 45 mins. Even though, my cheese wasn't completely cooked through, my husband and my kids thought the ziti was fantastic. My husband had three servings! I saw another post that said to sub the sour cream with ricotta. I'm sure that would be great, too. But, the sour cream makes this ziti taste amazing! Ziti tastes just about the same every where you go. It's kind of hard to screw it up. The sour cream makes it stand out.

I tried this dish and my husband and I loved, loved, loved it completely! Looking over the reviews, I did change mine a bit and used some shredded Colby/jack cheese because I had it in the fridge. I added tomato paste to my tomato sauce, used ground chicken instead of beef and layered it like this: ziti noodles, sauce, provolone cheese, sour cream, shredded mozzarella, noodles, sauce, provolone cheese and colby/jack, covered with foiled and baked at 350 for 30 minutes! Turned out delicious! Layering the noodles with the sauces allows the noodles to absurd the tomato sauce flavor!

I've made this Baked Ziti dish a couple times now and my wife can't stop saying how much she loves it while we eat. Oh yeah...I love it too; especially with pepper flakes! It's just so moist and delicious that you can't complain. I prefer mine with garlic bread, salad and red wine. 

For my family of three, this recipe is huge and lasts for at least three full meals (plus a couple of lunch bites), so I am thinking of reducing by half next time. First meal is the best; second meal is good and convenient to prepare, but we experience ziti burn out after that. I actually had to throw some out last time. :(

Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-09-09T20:20:03.593
helpfulCount:
1
userID:
4211236
Display Name:
Muscle Jock Chef
isPro:
False
followersCount:
17
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
52
favoritesCount:
578
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1440020.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good basic recipe to follow, I am sure. However I totally altered it in so many ways. I used ground turkey for which I seasoned very well in the morning w/ italian dressing mix , salt, pepper, worchester sauce, cyanne pepper, lawry's season salt, garlic powder, italian season, basil & onion powder. I did this at 9am that morning put in the fridge to marinate. I also diced up Kielbasa sausage small &   added it to regular breakfast hot sausage & chorizo  sausage.  The Chorizo added an extra flavor to it w/o making it taste mexican. I used the oil left from that to cook down the onions , fresh minced garlic, and fresh cut parsely.  I made my own sauce by added can of diced tomatoes, ketchup, & tomato paste w/ some added water to create more sauce. Like the other reviewers I mixed my pasta & sauce together then layered it w/ munster cheese, parmesan, feta, & mozzarella.  I wanted my baked Ziti meaty as well as cheesy. 

I topped the baked ziti w/ extra sharp  cheddar , mozzarella, & parmesan romano cheese which baked a nice crust on it. OMG it was so good, & it didn't feel heavy or too rich I think because I used ground turkey. 

You must definently cover the Ziti w/ foil while cooking in the oven so it will not  dry. I did a lot of prep work because of what I added but it was so worth it.. I will do this again. it was so much food I ended up with two pans, glad I made enough sauce everything came out perfect. This was my 1st time making Baked Ziti

text:
I was wary about using sour cream in baked ziti, but it was really very good.  I used extra sauce, just my preference, and as suggested I mixed the pasta with the sauce & meat then layered it 1/2 the noodles/sauce, all the provolone, all the sour cream, remaining noodles then 8oz of mozzarella and cooked it covered for all bot the last 10 min.
Delicious!  I'll definitely make it again.
(ps- those who had trouble finding sliced provolone, check your deli counter!)

text:
Quick & easy, kids & hubby loved it, so that makes me happy!  CHANGES: 1) Subbed 14.5 oz box wheat penne for ziti 2) added 4 tablespoons Parmesan, 1/2 tsp dry basil & 1/2 tsp Italian seasoning to sour cream 3) put small bit of sauce on bottom of pan to prevent sticking 4) layered 1/2 pasta, 1/2 sauce, provolone, sour cream mix, other 1/2 pasta, other 1/2 sauce, mozzarella.  Great go-to recipe for a quick weeknight meal that will keep them eating instead of complaining....thanks for the recipe Colleen!

text:
This was a phenomenal recipe. My husband loved it. It makes a lot and is very filling. We have tons of leftovers, which is ok by us. I did use whole wheat pasta, italian sausage instead of hamburger and light sour cream. It was amazing and you could taste a hint of the tang in sour cream. It went very well with the pasta dish. I did layer in this order: noodles, sauce, sour cream, provolone, noodles, sauce, mozzarella/parm. I baked it uncovered for 25 minutes and it was perfect.. defiinitely not dry at all.

Made it last night - soo good!! It was super easy, I am definitely a beginner and if I can do it anyone can do it! I used 1/2 ground beef and 1/2 hot italian sausage, added a little more flavor I think. Also I was worried about the sour cream, since I've never heard of sour cream in baked ziti before but it came out great!! I forgot to cover it, like others have suggested and it only made the outside pasta a little crunchy. Also, I put a little more mozzarella on top before the parmesean. This will definitely be made over and over again in the future!

country:
None
text:
Excellent recipe as many others have stated.  I have made this several times pretty much the way it is.  However tonight I added half a chopped green pepper, a small can of sliced black olives, and 1 lb. of Johnsonville smoked brats (which I sliced fairly thinly) to the hamburger when it was cooking.  These made it even more delicious!  I also changed the mozzarella to Italian blend, and after baking for 20 minutes put more on the top for the last 15 minutes.  I feel this casserole needs more time to bake because of its density.  I also put it into a pan one size larger than my 9X13 tonight, and it was still full to the top!  That was probably because of the extra pound of meat, but the larger pan is a good idea - regardless.  You will definitely need it.  I bet you could add Italian sausage or pepperoni or whatever spicy meats your family likes to give it a different flair for the next time you make it.  This brings it over the top compared to a pizza pasta casserole we used to make!

text:
Very good. Like others, I skipped the onions and did 1/2 ground beef, 1/2 sweet Italian sausage, then as I fried them up, I doctored with salt and pepper, garlic powder, and Italian seasonings. I used Ragu jarred spaghetti.  Like others, I also mixed up the sauce with the ziti for more coverage so no need to butter the bottom of the pan. Used low fat sour cream sparingly and that was fine. I actually put a bit too much cheese (WHAT?! Is that possible?) so next time I'll use a bit less of the cheese.  I volunteer to help feed the homeless downtown, and this would be an easy, inexpensive dish to feed the hordes with some adjustments in quantity.

So yummy! Easy! Quick! Made a ton!

text:
This is a really great recipe. I've made it a few times and everyone likes it alot. I do a few things differently. I double the provolone cheese. I also put the meat and sauce directly above the noodles, then the provolone above that. When you layer it like this the noodles get the sauce all mixed in with them instead of plain noodles with cheese on top, then sauce on top of that. Those are the only two things I do differently, this is an excellent recipe and tastes wonderful! Very easy to prepare ahead of time too!
