text:
My husband was soo pleased tonight when I made this, as was I! So delicious! However I made my own adjustments that I would recxomend and actually made it a tad healthier: 
No provolone cheese at all, instead of using all that spaghetti sauce add a small can of no salt added tomato sauce to your mix. Add a large green pepper oregano and Italian seasoning to your meat mixture. I used Italian sausage instead of ground beef. Mix in some garlic as well. Use fat free mozzarella and fat free sour cream. When layering sprinkle garlic roasted bread crumbs over each layer. Cover when baking. YUM! :)

text:
Made his Baked Ziti recipe 2 days ago.  My boyfriend immediately went back for seconds!  This was so easy and very fast to make.  Even rookies will be able to make this dish!  I seasoned the ground beef with minced garlic, oregeno, a little of worchestire sauce, and added a pinch of red crushed pepper for a kick.  Just like many of the other reviewers, I also layered my Ziti differently (pasta, sauce, provolone, sour cream, mozzarella).  I spooned the sauce mixture over the noodles. I used 12 slices of the Provolone non-smoked flavor cheee, Prego sauce, and light sour cream.  I used a foil pan since it was deeper than my other dishes.  Don't forget to cover the Ziti in foil before baking. An apple walnut salad went well, as our appetizer before eating the Ziti.

text:
Delicious! Someone mentioned that using ricotta would be more Italian. Provolone is an Italian cheese, too, and the Provolone/sour cream combo, in my opinion anyway, is much tastier than ricotta. Ziti may be traditionally made with ricotta, but personally I'd rather sacrifice authenticity for more flavorful results! This is an excellent recipe, as is. The only change I made was to add garlic. Oh, and I used penne instead of ziti only because I had penne on hand. I will definitely make this again!

userID:
3500863
Display Name:
xmansmommy
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was my very first ziti, and I couldn't have asked for a better recipe.  I started off by browning the meat with seasoning salt, minced garlic and freshly cracked black pepper.  I cut out the onion altogether and used low-fat mozzarella and sour cream.  Oh, and I simply sprayed my Pyrex with olive oil spray.  Our grater disappeared so I very thinly sliced down a 6 oz block of mozzarella.  I layered everything as described in the recipe, making sure to spread the mozzarella strips evenly.  Based off another review, I covered the dish prior to putting it in the oven.  What I pulled out...I didn't expect.  Amazing.  I sent some down to my boyfriend's father, the first thing I'd ever cooked for him except dessert and he raved about it.  So yes, this recipe will definitely stay in my rotation!!
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2011-08-20T06:02:52.843

country:
None
text:
This dish is a perfect way to enjoy a delicious meal for any occasion with almost no prep time. My family and I made this for Christmas Day and it was a huge hit! Somethings to add to this recipice would be basil and oregano on top of every layer and some cheddar cheese to sprinkle on the top. And don't be afraid to layer on that cheese! The point of the different kinds of cheeses is to taste all of their individual tastes which become hidden if you don't put enough of them on. Also the meat can be substituted for ground veggie meat for vegetarians. Also a great and easy recipe for kids too.

region:

country:
None
text:
I have made this Ziti a few times and it's a hit around our house. I even made it for my son's birthday party for our family and relatives of about 40 people and every one loved it.  One of the major change I make in this recipe is that I make my own sauce also on this site (Valerie's Bolognese Sauce) and use it in place of the jarred stuff as instructed in the recipe.   It makes the ziti super delicious and nothing beats the taste of homemade sauce.  I always, for our own preference, double the provolone and mozzarella cheeses, mix the pasta with the sauce before layering it, and cover with a foil while baking.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUMMY! I just made this dish and it turned out wonderful! I  made a few changes to make it healthier: I used ground turkey instead of beef (you can't even tell the difference and it cuts the saturated fat by more than half!).  I added diced green peppers, mushrooms and fresh garlic along with the onions and meat.  I used whole wheat ziti (this is a great way to add whole grains and fiber, if you don't really care for the taste of whole wheat, or if you have picky kids, try adding half whole wheat and half regular). I used reduced fat sour cream, and substituted one cup of sour cream for fat free ricotta cheese. I used mozzarella cheese made with 2% milk. All of these modifiations made a healthier dish, but it still tasted wonderful! My whole family loved it! I will definitely be adding this recipe to my rotation!

We had friends and family over for our weekly Sunday night dinner and it was a huge hit!  I did like many suggested and seasoned the beef a little bit with some Italian spices; separated the sauce into 1/3 and 2/3 portions.  Mixed the pasta with the 2/3 portion and used the 1/3 sauce only portion for the upper sauce layer.  Totally agree with mixing the pasta with the sauce.  The rest I pretty much followed the instructions, but was sure to cover with tin foil while baking.  In the end the dish was delicious and easy to prepare; highly recommend.

text:
Loved this!  While browning the meat, I added onion, green and red peppers, minced garlic, italian seasoning, a dash of worcester sauce, crushed red pepper flakes, and a sprinkle of salt and pepper.  Since my grocery store was out of ziti noodles, I bought rotini, and it was just as good.  I layered as suggested in the recipe.  I couldn't get provolone cheese, so I bought an italian mix which contained provolone, parmesan, emmental, and mozzarella.  On top, I sprinkled crushed red pepper flakes.  Everyone really enjoyed it.  I cut the recipe in half and there was still too much!  I'll make it for a potluck next time, where there'll be more people!

text:
This was just WONDERFUL!!! I will definitely make this again and again! The sour cream was a definite plus. I did make a few small changes, but not enough to take away from the original recipe. I used low fat sour cream and mixed with it about 6 oz of ricotta cheese. I also used 3 cloves of minced garlic and, because I increased the amount of meat by about 1/3 lb, I used a little more spaghetti sauce. I used Preggo's mushroom sauce and put in a pinch of baking soda in to cut the acidity.  When I cooked the pasta (I used penne as that is what was on hand and it is much like ziti) I under-cooked it by half, so it would finish cooking in the oven.  I took the advice of others and mixed some of the sauce directly into the pasta and covered it so it would not dry out.  Thank you for sharing such a delicious and versatile recipe with us!

Great! Easy! I followed directions and ingredients, but halved the recipe as there's only two of us. This is comfort food at its best. I can't believe that I haven't made this yet, and I am so glad that I did.  Like others, I was a little skeptical about sour cream in an Italian pasta dish.  I had 1/2 cup of cottage cheese to use up, so I added that in with 1 cup of sour cream and used that.  I also only had penne pasta, so that is what I used.  I made my own sauce with meat, and this dish was outstanding.  All of my kids had seconds, and the great thing is that there is enough leftovers for them to have this for lunch tomorrow.  Thanks for a perfect pasta recipe.

text:
Everyone that has tried this just loves it and asks for recipe!    I really don't change recipe around at all, other than I don't put in onion due to taste preference, and I use ground Italian turkey sausage- it gives it a nice flavor without the extra fat from actual Italian sausage.  (If you have never tried it, my husband didn't even know the difference!)    I do put sauce on the noodles before putting the provolone on.    My only complaint is that sometimes the middle isn't quite hot when cooked for only 30 minutes, so I cook it a little longer.  I use Ragu Organic sauce.  Just my preference of course.  But again, I can't say enough about this meal.  So good, and easy.  And even better the next day!  (And the next, and the next...)

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I couldn't find ziti at my supermarket so I used mini penne, which to me was just as good. However, I would change the way it is layered. After the noddles I would put the sauce on top because by putting the cheese (especially sliced cheese) on top of the noodles the sauce didn't really reach it and my bottom layer was just noodle that has to be mixed in. I didn't really care for this but I suppose thats my fault because I should have expected this to be creamy because of the sour cream and I wasn't looking for creamy. However, my husband devoured like three bowls which is why it got four stars. So overall, I would just make sure your sauce gets to the noodles by changing the order and this will be pretty tasty (as long as you like sour cream and want a creamy texture)

text:
my friend made this for me after the birth of my 3rd child. and now, this is my new favorite recipe to make for other people... new moms, people who have been in the hospital, whatever.  to make it more healthy, i've changed a few things.  I use whole wheat pasta, fat free sour cream, spaghetti sauce that comes with veggies in it, plus i chop up one zucchini to add to the sauce.  i use reduced fat cheese and i also use ground turkey instead of beef.  this is so easy. i pair it with a simple salad and some garlic bread or some simple rolls... yum!  also, hubby doesn't like things too creamy so i usually use less sour cream when i make it for our family.  but, honestly, you can't really mess this one up... which makes it perfect for me!

I made this pretty much exactly as instructed.  My only changes were covering the noodles in sauce before starting to layer and covering the dish with aluminum foil before baking.  The meat was optional in this recipe so I thought it would be a good vegetarian dish to try.  It turned out to be okay but not worth making again.  I thought it was lacking something... probably the ground beef.  I don't recommend this recipe as is to vegetarians.  If you try it, you might want to add mushrooms or some other veggies.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/6293168.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Delicious.  I love this recipe.  I read the reviews before making this and did alter it a bit.  I sometimes use penne pasta.  When I brown the hamburger (very lean) I sprinkle on chili powder, nutmeg & celery salt to taste and 1 T minced onions (If I want some heat, I add red pepper flakes.  I use 2-26 oz. jars of Prego Roasted Red Pepper & Garlic sauce and 1 jar of Prego 3-cheese sauce.  I layer it in a 9x13 pan as follows:  1/2 of the pasta, 1/2 of the sauce, sour cream, about seven slices of provolone cheese to cover completely, remaining pasta, about 7 oz. shredded mozzarella, the rest of the sauce and top with shredded parmesan.  Then I cover the pan and bake.  Whenever I make this everyone raves about it and I am always asked for the recipe.

I read lots of the reviews before making this, and did make some changes to the recipe purely because we like things with more "spice".  I used both sweet italian sausage and hot italian sausage (a total of 1.5 lb), several cloves of garlic and italian spices in the pasta sauce.  I also used 1.5 C of sour cream and a half cup of ricotta cheese.  But still felt that I followed the recipe for the most part.  The result was stellar!   I will definitely make this again for a crowd - everyone loved it.

text:
This was great!  I'm sure it would be just perfect as written but I didn't feel like going to the store. Others reviewers mentioned it not being "real" Italian....I don't think it is meant to be.  It is just a good easy weekday meal for a hungry family.  So - I used my own homemade spaghetti sauce (yummy) and did not have provolone so used a dry aged cheddar (definitely not Italian) and doubled the parmesan.  I always pour sauce into the bottom of the pan and then layer up from there. I also mixed the sour cream with the ziti before layering so we wouldn't get a clump of sour cream.  Very, very good recipe with lots of leftovers.  thanks

This was amazing!! We couldn't stop eating it. Don't listen to the other reviews that say to use ricotta instead of sour cream. If you want a Ziti recipe that uses ricotta there are plenty on here. The sour cream is what makes this recipe! The only changes I made were that I used ground turkey instead of beef and whole wheat noodles and a mixture of fat free and light sour cream and just used the cheese I had on hand which were mozzarella and muenster. I would give this 10 stars if I could!! Oh I also mixed the sauce with the bottom layer of noodles as another reviewer suggested and I did cover it while I bakes it.

Display Name:
Dancing Queen

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/358767.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I prepared this recipe for a dinner party and after reading tons of reviews I made mine the following way: Boiled one 14 ounce whole wheat penne noodles for 8 mins. While that was boiling I browned the ground beef with onions and garlic, drained, and then simmered with sauce. I layered as follows: sauce mixture, noodles, cheese, sour cream, repeat. This filled my 9x13 pan to the max. Covered and let chill over night. I then took this out an hour before I wanted to bake to let it reach room temp before cooking COVERED. This recipe was well received with most people going back for seconds. I even have a lot left over, so this can totally feed a large crowd, and what is great is that it can be prepared before hand. My family doesn't like whole wheat pasta, but cooked this way they had no idea. Loved it! Thanks.

My family loved this ziti. However if you are like me and find that ground beef to be stringy, tough, or grainy substitute it for 1 pound of meatballs. We used frozen meatballs (because they are always on hand), thaw them in the microwave and tear them apart. It is also how they make the dish at one of my favorite restraunts!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/222780.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was really good!  I made a few changes based on things I wanted to use up.  I don't like onions so I omitted them and used a couple of cloves of garlic.  I had a container of cottage cheese with chives that I bought by mistake so I put it into the blender with a little milk to sub for the sour cream.  Once the noodles were cooked I mixed them with the cottage cheese. I put a layer of sauce down first in the pan, then the coated noodles, a layer of the provolone cheese, a sprinkling of fresh basil, then more sauce, noodles, sauce and the shredded cheese layer.  This made an almost overflowing 9X13" glass pan.  It ended up bubbling over in my oven, next time I will put the pan on a cookie sheet to catch the overflow.  A great recipe!

None
text:
Delicious!  The only changes I made was to substitute penne pasta for the ziti ( I didn't have any on hand)and I only made half and cooked it in an 8x8 pan. I just used regular Prego sauce. My husband absolutely loves his mom's lasagna - and he said this was better and requested that I add it to the "favorite" recipes!  Thank you Colleen! Update: I've made this with penne pasta and ziti, and I actually prefer the penne.  It's not a huge difference, but the sauce sticks to the ridges of the penne, while it tends to slide right off of the ziti.  Still delicious either way!  Just make sure you cover the pan while baking or it will dry out.

text:
Good, simple recipe. As others did, I switched a few layers to allow the sauce to reach the bottom layer of pasta. Also, I used ground turkey instead of beef. Not quite as tasty, but healthier. A final note about the pan size: it's a tight squeeze, but once I had the second layer of pasta in, I pushed down on everything, which seemed to compress things enough for the final layers. Of course, you could just use a bigger pan...

text:
Good recipe, pretty basic stuff but hearty and tasty.  I suppose it goes without saying, but your choice of jarred pasta sauce will make or break this recipe.  As long you choose a favorite, you're just making regular meat pasta and layering it with a little cheese.  No brainer!  I made the recipe as written.  After trying it with the sour cream, I think next time I will go back to my old lasagna stand by and use small curd cottage cheese (or ricotta) mixed with an egg for the filling.  The sour cream was good and easy, but I prefer my "lasagna" MY way :-)  Again, very basic, pretty easy, and plenty tasty (with the right sauce).

text:
This definatly was good! I made a few changes in the way I layered it and cut down on the sour cream. I think had I not I would have given this 5 stars. With that being said here is what I did: I halved the recipe (was only cooking for two) used about 1/3 cup sour cream (half would've been 3/4) used Barilla's Baking sauce and layered as follows. Half of the ziti, half sauce, prov. cheese, sour cream. Other half ziti, sauce and so on. Next time, and they're DEFINATLY will be a next time I will layer as directed exept the top layer will do sauce first then cheese. And of course you must baked covered! Yuuuum!! My fiance said it was SOOOO GOOD, and he is the HARDEST to please! Thanks for the recipe!

text:
This recipe gets a five with a few alterations. I followed several reccommendations by other reveiwers. I sauteed 4 cloves of garlic with the hamburger and onion. Also added some oregano to the meat. I added 1 pound of ricotta cheese and an egg to the noodles. I put a little sauce on the bottom of the pan and layered 1/2 the noodles, then 6 slices of provolone then 1/2 the sauce then repeated the layer. Put slices of mozzarella on the top. This was very good and wonderful reheated. I served with home made bread sticks and salad.

We just finished having this for dinner and it was really good. I made the recipe as stated, only using a bag of shredded Italian Blend instead of mozzarella and freshly shredded Parmesan. I needed to use up some sour cream anyway so opted to try it this way as written. I'm not sure it was the "best" but it was very good this way!  I just changed my rating to 5 stars... I have this all the time now. I did sub the ricotta and actually like sour cream better, so 5 stars and "the best" it is!

This was so yummy! It makes ALOT, so invite your friends! I made a few changes based on others suggestions by mixing the finished sauce and meat mixture with the ziti so that when it baked the sauce was disbursed evenly. I used two different types of sauce, 5 cheese Bertelloni and Sockarooni. Added some italian seasoning, minced garlic, seasoned salt with the beef/onion mixture. text:
I have been making this recipe for a few years now, and everyone always requests it for special occassion dinners.  We had it for our anniversary last night!  The only thing I do differently is use the whole tub of sour cream (2 cups), the entire 8 oz packages of provolone and mozzarella.  I've read reviews about using ricotta instead of sour cream, but I love the creaminess of the sour cream, and with all the extra cheese I put on there, I think the ricotta would be overkill.

After reading some reviews about too much pasta sauce, too watery, etc, I wanted to point out what I use.  I always use the Great Value brand of spaghetti sauce "Onions and Garlic".  The amount of food this makes does overflow out of the pan, but last night I tried dividing it into two smaller dishes, and that worked perfectly.

text:
This recipe is definitely 5 star material.  I decided to surprise my girlfriend with this recipe when she came home from work--she loved it!  I added a few small variations to the recipe itself, however.  For one, even though the recipe does not say it, I recommend you bake it covered.  Other than that, I decided to change the layer variation a little.  Instead of starting with Ziti Noodles, I started with a Ziti/Sauce mixture so that there would be appropriate moisture at the bottom.  I also added italian sausage to my meat sauce.  I recommend the sausage for anyone who likes a nice kick to their sauce.  Other than that, amazing recipe!

text:
Ohhhhh such a good recipe!!! I decided to use 1 lb of Ground beef and 1/2 lb of mild sausage. I also used 2- 1 lb containers of pasta sauce, added oregeno, parsley, and a heaping spoonful of minced garlic. I thought it was important to keep the pasta moist so I layered 1/2 the pasta first and mixed it with 1/2 of the sauce/ meat mixture. I used extra provolone cheese... probably 3 oz more than called for. Don't skip the sour cream... it seems weird but it mixes with the provolone cheese and makes a creamy white sauce layer in the middle of the ziti. The last change I made was using a whole 8 oz block of mozzerella cheese. This recipe will be made all the time in my house... the family just loved it!!!

text:
OH MY GAWD! I am a fan of baked ziti, and this is by far one of the best baked ziti I have ever had!  I used ground turkey (a lot healthier and cheaper!) instead of ground beef. Browned it with the onions, added 2 cloves chopped up garlic and seasoned it with italian seaoning, ground pepper and Lawry's seasoned salt. Then I added the spaghetti sauce...I only had one jar instead of two. And I layered in a baking dish as followed: 1/2 of the cooked penne rigate pasta (oh I used a 12 oz bag), 1/2 of the sauce, provolone, sour cream, ADDED cottage cheese (about 6 tbsp), pasta, sauce, and the italian blend shredded cheese (the 6 type one), and then parmesian cheese(i only had the powdered). Baked it for 35 mins and came out wonderful! My fiance hates cottage cheese and loved this recipe! he didnt just have seconds, he had thirds! this is now my favorite dish to make and serve! thank you thank you thank you!!!!

text:
NOTE: The cooking time of 1 hour and 45 minutes at the top of the recipe contradicts the 30 minute baking time at the bottom of the recipe. I baked it for 45 minutes and it came out just fine.

My family enjoyed this delicious alternative to my always well-received recipe for baked ziti - I thought this was much lighter in taste and creamier with a more interesting texture, thanks to the sour cream. 
I also sauted one finely chopped onion and added it to the tomato sauce for extra flavor (so it wasn't so bland).

text:
Yummy...I did 3/4 cup sour cream and 3/4 cup ricotta cheese(needed to use it up before it expired).  I also shredded my provolone cheese since I bought a block of it.  I layered starting with sauce at the bottom to avoid drying out the noodles(as others also wrote) and ended with a layer of mozzerella cheese since I like mine to have the cheese on top.  I also used FRESH parmesan and romano cheeses (really makes a HUGE difference to use fresh).  I never though sour cream would go well in this but it certainly did.  I did make one batch with meat and one without and they were both equally great.

text:
This is excellent!! I added a bunch of spices to the meat as it cooked. (more garlic, italian herbs, onion powder, red pepper flakes) and used other reviewers advice of mixing the pasta right in the sauce/meat mixture rather than layering. I used penne pasta because I wasn't paying attention in the store, lol and it turned out great.
I made this a day ahead and kept it covered in the fridge until the next evening. The only thing I will do next time is make more of the cheese/sour cream mixture to make that layer bigger. I used fat free Ricotta and fat free sour cream and you'd never know it :)
Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
This recipe was GREAT!  We made it vegetarian style without the ground meat, and like others on the list I cut the sour cream down to 1/2 cup or so, and added a cup of ricotta and added an egg and dried parsley (I mixed the ricotta, egg, parsley, and parmesan together and layered this over the provalone).  I also put a layer of sauce on the bottom of the dish to add moisture and a little more tomato flavor to the bottom noodles.  My husband raved over this, and it will definitely be added to my frequent recipes list.  I'll add meat, or spinach, or extra garlic, or a layer of pesto and pine nuts for variations.  This comes out a bit like lasagne, but easier and less finicky than lasagne noodles.  Thanks for a great and easy recipe!

text:
This was really, really good.  I am giving it 4 stars just because I did change it up a bit.  I used rigatoni.  I also used Turkey Bolognese that is an excellent recipe from Rachael Ray's daytime TV show, I think honestley, that was the key as to why it was so tasty I love that sauce!!!I make a big batch and freeze some.  I used low fat everything.  I mixed about a cup of light sour cream with a heaping 1/2 cup of ricotta.  I had some prepared pesto from another recipe and I hate for anything to go to waste so I mixed that with the sour cream and ricotta along with a handful or grated parmesan.  I also mixed the sauce with the noodles verses pouring it over as a layer.  On top I added reduced fat Sargento 4 italian cheese and also added grated parmesan.  This makes a lot but a great meal to carry over for a couple of days.  This was really good.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Here are, I hope, a few helpful notes on this recipe.  I made it exactly as written, except to substitute half ricotta cheese for the full amount of sour cream.  As noted by many others this recipe makes a lot and the sour cream makes it very rich which also makes it difficult to eat a large portion.  I believe it serves 10 - 12, unless you are accustomed to eating larger portions and are not having side dishes such as salad and bread. Some reviewers who have not liked this dish have commented on the "tangy" flavor of the sour cream.  I didn't notice this, probably because I used half ricotta, half sour cream.  That being said, the sour cream does tend to blend with the spaghetti sauce which gives it an overall cream tomato sauce look and taste.  If you are a straight tomato sauce purist you might not like this recipe.

text:
A hit!  I'm not much of a cook but I took on this recipe for Christmas Eve dinner with the family (and the first time I've made dinner for the family).  Everybody raved about it!  Even my picky brother-in-law (who always has an excuse why not to eat at family gatherings) helped himself to some!

I did eyeball many measurements, using as much sauce, cheese and sour cream as it looked like it needed.  I also used 1/2 ground turkey and 1/2 mild bulk sausage.  Used some extra provolone on the top, and split up the sour cream so that half was in the middle and half on top.

Hubby says this one is a keeper!

userID:
2514978
Display Name:
AmyLou
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0
madeRecipesCount:
2
favoritesCount:
0
recipesCount:

reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614284.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a very good pasta recipe!  I have made it as written and then a healthier version without giving up taste!
Substitutions:
1. Whole Wheat Penne in place of Ziti
2. Fat Free Sour Cream
3. Fat Free Mozzerella
4. Ground Buffalo or Ground Turkey in place of beef
5. Pam spray in place of butter
6. Natural Spaghetti Sauce (variety of brands)

Even with these substitutions, my family RAVES over this.  The substitutions takes away most of the fat, but none of the taste and texture!  If you are a "Weight Watcher" you can easily figure out the points.  You get a whole lot of bang for your dieting buck with this one!

Mix some sauce with the pasta to keep it all moist.  Make sure to cover it with foil sprayed with Pam and bake until bubbly.  Then, let it sit for about 10 minutes to set up!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a staple in my household! I changed some of the preparation steps: boil the noodles and cook the meat/onions. (usually half an onion is enough) Mix all of it together with 2 full bottles of sauce into one big pot. Grease the pan and put half of the mixture in, layer with cheese. spoon in the other half, layer with cheese again. Every bite will have meaty cheesy saucy goodness! I also replace cottage cheese for ricotta if I'm going to the store anyways. (more authentic) Replacing the beef with Italian sausage is great for taste, but if you're going for health I've used ground turkey instead which is also delicious. (you can barely tell once everything else is mixed in)

text:
This recipe is a huge hit with my boyfriend and his friends EVERY TIME! I did find it hard to spread the sour cream easily, so one thing that I do to make life easier is put the sour cream in a sandwich bag and snip the end, almost like I am piping for a cake.  The sour cream to spread evenly throughout the ziti while it is baking...I also add a small can of italian style stewed tomatoes (chopped up) and a small can of tomato sauce.  This is just my preference though, the recipe is still great as is

This is our favorite baked ziti recipe. Depending on what we have on hand, I've used ground beef, ground turkey or Italian sausage and it always turns out delicious!! The greatest joy was when my Italian Mother-in-Law was very impressed with this dish! I follow the recipe as is except I brown the ground beef or ground turkey with onions, minced garlic, Italian seasoning and some cayenne pepper for a wonderful flavor. I will try using part riccota and sour cream next time as some of the reviewers suggested. Thank you for this wonderful recipe.

text:
This is one of my favorite pasta recipes.  I followed the advice of some others and stirred my pasta sauce, noodles and meat together to make sure that everything had a good coating of sauce.  I definitely think that makes a huge difference.  I really like that the recipe uses sour cream over ricotta cheese because I'm not a huge fan of ricotta.  I've made the recipe several times now and while it makes a ton I enjoy eating the leftovers.

text:
This dish was fantastic!  It was so easy to make, very economical and tasted GREAT!  I made this for a sick friend and decided to prepare extra for us.  My whole family loved it - even my youngest who is one of the world's pickiest eaters!  I was hesitant about the sour cream since I don't like sour cream, but it was fantastic!!  So glad I didn't leave it out. I added 1 tbs. Italian seasoning, a pinch of sugar, 1 tsp minced garlic (from a jar - not the dried kind), and 1 tsp garlic salt to the sauce (I used Ragu Robusto onion and garlic sauce) then mixed the meat sauce and pasta together as others suggested.  I will definitely be making this again and again!

text:
I made this recipe for a Potluck night with friends last night.  I substituted ground turkey for ground beef, used light sour cream, and part skim mozzerella cheese.  Also used a couple dashes of Cholula Hot Sauce and 2 tbs of sugar to the sauce.  Bake uncovered at 475 degrees for the last 10 minutes to give it a nice bubbly slightly browned topping.  My friends were raving about the dish and many had seconds.  Delish!!!

The nearly perfect comfort food. I combined the sauce/meat mixture(I used venison sausage) with the slightly undercooked noodles (penne).  Layered as follows: 1/2 penne/sauce mixture, provalone, sour creme, other 1/2 of penne/sauce mixture, mozzerella cheese. I didn't need the parm cheese when layered this way.  Covered, of course. I also like to add additional oregano and basil to whichever sauce I use for this dish.  I plan to use diced green peppers in the mix next time, and maybe a sausage-pepperoni combination.

This recipe is so good. We make this and save it, and when we cook it again, it is as good as the first time. The only change I make to this recipe is I put sauce on the bottom of the pan, and then I start to layer noodles, provolone, sour cream, mozzarella, and then start allover again. and on the last layer I mix the mozzarella with the parmesean cheese. we have requests to make this as a frozen meal for familes that have just had a baby....I don't know anyone that doesn't like this!

Display Name:
HomeschoolMomtoBoys

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The first time I made this I did it exactly as is and loved it.  The second time and now every time, I just use an Italian cheese blend for all the cheese.  I just divide it up.  It's easier this way and I think I like it a little better.  Either way, this recipe is awesome!

UPDATE:  I've been making this recipe for years now.  Love it! It's my go-to for a crowd because it makes a lot and can easily be doubled into two pans of it.  I have started adding a layer of pepperoni in with it and it's wonderful!  Sometimes I use provolone sometimes all mozzarella, but it's always great.   Add in a bell pepper too for even more flavor. Really you cannot go wrong with this recipe.  As is or with a few additions, it's always great.  I've never made a bad "batch."

The only thing that I do recommended doing differently than the recipe is the order of the layering.  Put some of the meat sauce in the bottom of your pan, then 1/2 pasta, then sour cream, more meat sauce, pepperoni (if using), cheese, rest of pasta, rest of meat sauce, and lastly more cheese.  If you layer the provolone before the first meat sauce, the sauce doesn't get into the bottom layer of your pasta and while it doesn't ruin the dish, it's less dry if you sauce it first.

text:
With a few minor changes this was the best ziti ever!!!! My boys ate the whole thing in two days. Here are the changes I made: I used italian sausage and added garlic and mushrooms to the meat mixture. Also, when doing the layers, I put a thin amount of sauce on the bottom (to keep the noodles from sticking), then 1/2 the noodles, 1/2 the sauce, the sour cream, 1/2 of BOTH cheeses, then repreated (except for the sour cream) and topped with parmesan...awsome!

text:
Awesome! I took the advice of others and assembled a smaller version into a mid-size plastic container that I froze. That made the remaining amount of ingredients perfect for a 9" x 13" baking pan. I also mixed a little of the sauce into the bottom layer of pasta and covered the dish as recommended. I removed the cover after 20  minutes to allow the Parmesan cheese an opportunity to get a little color. Other than that and adding about a teaspoon of minced garlic and a couple of tablespoons of pesto to the sauce mixture, I followed the recipe exactly, and it was delicious!

I only gave it 4 stars because I had to season the heck out of it to make it taste really good (I didnt even bother not seasoning the meat with a little bit of italian seasoning and a little spoon of tomato paste mixed with a splash of water the first time I made it, but I know it wouldnt have been as good)  I get pretty generic spagetti sauce because i like to season it myself and sometimes I make my own sauce for other recipes and freeze what's left over for this.  I use far less sour cream and add ricotta to the mix (because I always have tons on hand) and it's GREAT.  Dont be scared to add your own seasoning, for some reason this recipe lacks that.

The sour cream is what separates this recipe from others that I have tried.  Yummy!  Update 10/8/09 - I made this for a Halloween Bunko party and did as the others suggested and mixed the sour cream with the ziti and it worked so much better plus I used some mild Italian sausage...it was so good.  I'm changing my four stars to five.  I made a batch and a half and it made two large casseroles with plenty to eat for everyone.  I also prepared it the day before and put it in the refrigerator to bake the next day (just bring it to room temperature before you bake it).  It had rave reviews from my guests.

text:
This is a great recipe!  I made a few minor changes: I used italian sausage instead of ground beef and added a few cloves of fresh minced garlic along with the onion.  Also, I used 1/2 sour cream and 1/2 ricotta and changed the layering order (pasta, sauce, sour cream/ricotta, provolone).  It makes a huge amount as mentioned in previous reviews...I divided mine into 2 baking dishes - made one for dinner and popped the other in the freezer for a "ready to bake" meal.  Great for a covered dish dinner too!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
The beauty of this recipe is that it is so easy. It's not gourmet cuisine, but you can alter it just about any way you want to suit your taste and it still turns out. You can change the cheeses, vary the meat, add vegetables, or spice up the sauce, and it gets even better. You can put it together the night before or freeze it (if you cover it with foil you should protect it first with plastic wrap, as the tomato in the sauce could ruin the foil). The ziti is NOT dry, which is often a problem with this kind of recipe. I will keep this on hand and have fun with the variations. Thank you, Colleen, for a versatile casserole!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/3055.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading the most helpful reviews.  I set out to make this dish.  I used a tomato and basil sauce and a tomato and spicy garlic sauce.  I mixed the meat, sauce and noodles together. I put 1/2 of the sauced noodles on the bottom, thenI put on the provolone slices and spread the sour cream over it. I put the rest of the sauced noodles on top of this. I put grated mozzerella cheese over all, sprinkled with a good parmesan cheese; sprayed a piece of foil with "Pam" and put it  covered into the oven for 30 minutes; took off foil and let it brown for about another 10-15 minutes.  An easy-cheesy homecooked meal without a lot of effort.  PS.  I thought about using ricotta but decided against it.  I like my lasagna and wanted something with a different flavor.  My teenaged sons loved this!  Thanks Colleen

text:
How can you not love this ziti recipe? The mixes of cheese are really good. I made this 5 hours ahead of time and let the dish sit in the refrigerator to blend. I used a block of mozzarella and sliced it for the layer instead of store bought shredded. You might think you'd miss the ricotta from this dish,,, but the sour cream tastes great. You don't miss the ricota.

text:
This was great, although I did make a couple of "minor" changes.  I seasoned the water that I cooked the ziti in with Italian seasoning and garlic powder.  I also seasoned the ground beef with salt, pepper, and garlic powder.  And I added 2 packages frozen creamed spinach (I cooked it first in microwave of course) in between the layers. Although the ingredients were a little costly (I think I spent about $18), it made so much that the price per serving was economical.  I had to use a 9.5 x 13.5 casserole dish though and it still almost spilled over.  I will certainly make this again.  Thanks for a great recipe.

text:
I've never had ziti before, so picked this for my first recipe. I also thought I didn't like sour cream at all, but in this dish it baked to a consistency sort of like ricotta in a lasagna. It was pretty good, but makes a lot of food for one person (probably 5-6 meals for me). It did wind up a bit watery, though. I guess the sauce mixture needed more simmering to remove water. Also, other beginning cooks (like me) should notice that you really do need a LARGE skillet for this.

text:
This recipe tastes like a lasagne but is much simpler to make.  It was sooooo good.  The family really enjoyed it.  In addition to the onion and ground beef, add 2 tbsp of minced garlic for added flavor. 
I would suggest mixing 1/3 sauce with 1/2 pasta as the first layer, then top with the grated provolone cheese, sour cream, 1/3 sauce mixed with rest of pasta, mozzarella cheese, rest of sauce.  It was good without the Parmesan cheese.  This recipe is a keeper.  Thanks for sharing.

text:
I made this tonight for my boyfriend and my two kids, hoping that I had hit the jackpot.  The end result was good; my boyfriend went for seconds, but my kids were on the fence about it (probably because the presentation was something that they weren't used to).  My daughter kept examining each bite as though it were a science experiment...my son, usually a hearty eater, claimed he was full before being half-done his portion.
All in all a good recipe; I will make it again and try some of the suggestions of the others (ie. use italian sausage, use more sour cream & cheese, more sauce,etc).  The sour cream really made the dish.  I still think my lasagna's better though :-)

Very good, VERY cheesy!  The other reviews were right. It's almost impossible to fit all of the ingredients into one 9x13 dish. I just didn't use all the noodles and sauce. text:
Thank you to all of the other reviewers for your suggestions. I added 1 tablespoon of minced garlic when browning the meat, I also used half ground meat and half italian sausage. I used "Classico's Mushroom & Ripe Olive" jar sauce and I also changed the way it was layered: 1/2 pasta, 1/2 sauce mixture, provolone cheese, sour cream, remaining pasta, remaining sauce, mozzarella & parmasean cheese. I also used a 9x13 disposable Reynolds tin baking dish, sprayed with Pam and covered the dish with foil and baked it for 30 minutes and it was perfect! Use whatever kind of sauce that suits your preference. Next time I am going to make it using "Brian's Favorite Sauce" which is my husbands all time favorite and has amazing flavor.

text:
Like everyone else I loved this recipe. It was very easy to assemble and was very delicious to eat. The only hard part was spreading the sour cream on the provolone cheese. But I managed. 
The end result was a real keeper. I used 8 oz. of mozzarella (the whole bag) and it was great. For the spaghetti sauce I used Classico Mushroom and Garlic and we thought it was perfect. I added some italian seasoning since that is always what I do to sauce. And a crazy thing is that my grocery store didn't have any ziti. I looked and looked and finally just bought penne. I went on the Net to see what the differnce is and decided there really wasn't any. This is a dish I will definitely make when company comes over. This was my trial run to make sure we liked it before I served it. I hate to make something new the first time for company and then not have it turn out so good.

text:
I've tried this recipe numerous times, and it always gets rave reviews from everyone. Missing some of the ingredients, I modified the recipe slightly, and found it to be equally satisfying. Armed with only 10 oz jars of sauce, rather than the recommended 26 oz, I added chopped Roma tomatoes and red wine, and simmered it with the sauce. Additionally, I was out of provolone cheese, so I substituted a small amount of Kraft Roasted Garlic Cheddar, and a small amount of leftover Fontina cheese, for the bottom layer, and it added a very nice flavour. Thanks so much for the recipe!

text:
This was an excellent dish that lasted 4 nights for my husband, another adult, and me.  It definitely requires a deeper baking dish, use one specially made for lasagna to fit all the ingredients.  I like to add 1/4 cup brown sugar to the sauce as it simmers to give it a nice flavor, and instead of using 2 jars of spaghetti sauce I used one jar of sauce and added a 28 oz can of seasoned diced tomatos and two small cans of tomato paste.  My husband claimed this was his favorite pasta dish ever!

text:
I had to use penne pasta. Used one 1lb.10oz jar Ragu parmesan and romano sauce and 2- 8oz. cans Hunts tomato sauce. Omitted the onion and added 1/2 tsp chopped garlic. Also added a small can sliced mushrooms. Also I didn't read the reviews and only used 1 cup sour cream. I would use all of it next time and add some ricotta or cottage cheese next time. My husband is italian and he can always tell if I use jarred sauces. He does not like them. This has not been husband tested yet,but the kids liked it. I don't think he'll like it. Daughter likes my homemade baked mac aroni better with homemade sauce. I know this way is fast and easy but the next time I have any homemade sauce left in the freezer, I will use that instead. I liked the cheeses but will add more moz. and parm next time in the layers. This makes ALOT!!! Thanks Colleen!

text:
This recipe is DEEELISH! It is really really easy to make as well.

Although, I did not use 2 jars of tomato sauce- to me this is MUCH too much for the amount of pasta in the recipe. Instead, I used 1 jar of tomato sauce (one with tomato, garlic and portobello mushrooms) and covered the dish for 28 minutes. For the last 2 minutes, I turned the oven to BROIL to allow the cheese to bubble a bit.  Yummmm!  It was a total hit with my family, absolutely DELICIOUS. Thanks for the recipe. A keeper!

text:
I have never rated a recipe before, but this one is worth the time. I have never made baked ziti that has tasted this good before. The mixture of the 2 cheeses and the sour cream make all the difference. I made this with sausage and just layered it on top before that last layer of sauce. This will be the only ziti I will ever make again. Even my picky boys had second helpings.

This was easy to make and tasted great - suggested substitutions for lacto-ovo vegetarians: 1 lb.ground TVP for ground meat, 3/4 c. non-fat sour cream and 3/4 c. 1% fat cottage cheese for full fat sour cream, 2 jars low fat vegetarian pasta sauce, 12 oz. low fat mozzarella for all cheese and 2 TBSP Parmesan flavour "Veggie Topping" (made from organic tofu)

text:
I was very disappointed with this recipe after reading so many great reviews. I did modify it as some reviewers had suggested by using 1/2 ricotta cheese with the sour cream, and using the Classico Tomato and Basil sauce. The sauce had a bad taste, but the cheese/sour cream mixture was fine. Plus, the 13x9 pan was way too small. I had enough left over to fill a casserole dish as well. If I ever try it again I will not use the Classico sauce and use a much bigger pan.

What a shame that I can't give this recipe 6 stars. It's delicious and so easy to prepare. I think it will be a long time before I make lasagna again. We don't care for provolone cheese, so I substituted sliced sharp cheddar. I made half the recipe but used the full pound of ground beef. I also baked this half recipe in a Corningware baking pan that's a tad smaller than 8X11" and it wasn't too big. Thanks for sharing, Colleen, this is now a favorite in this family.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I recently used this recipe for a wedding reception and used the scaled units. One bit of info if you are using this amount(for 100 people), you may want to cook less ziti then it calls for because with that amt. it will continue to cook in the colander. With everything going on, I had to leave it many times and came back to sticky ziti. I did put it back in the pan and ran cold water over it and drained it again. It worked well. I should have put a teaspoon of oil in the water while cooking the ziti, that might of helped. Just don't overcook the ziti. We are still getting compliments on the food. We also froze the leftovers and they are just as tasty so this could be made ahead and frozen for the big day.

text:
I'm Italian and having cooked and eaten great Italian food over the years, I have to say that this is the best Baked Ziti I have ever eaten. The creamy layer of provolone & sour cream in the middle add great taste & texture. I added extra garlic & about 2 tblsp. of sugar to the sauce ("Five Brothers" or "Classico" Tomato & Basil were great)to give it a mildly sweeter taste. It is best to make this in a 9 X 13 in. pan - it was filled to the top. I then topped it with Kraft Parmesan cheese with garlic....it was fantastic!

text:
I made this recipe for my family using Delmonte's "Traditional" flavor spahetti sauce in a 26.5 oz. can.  I also added a tablespoon of minced garlic and just a wee bit of salt and pepper to the meat as I browned it.  Also added a dab or two of Worchestershire sauce to the meat as it was browning. The results were fabulous.  The whole family loved it and I have since passed the recipe to two friends who have made it and loved it.  This one is a definate keeper.  It taste even better warmed up the next day.
Thanks to the author for sharing this recipe.

Suzy Alexander

userID:

Display Name:
Pamela J
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614249.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
After reading a 2-star review, I took some recommended changes and made a few others.  Substituted 1-lb of low-fat ricotta cheese for 1 c. of sour cream, blended it 1/2 c. sour cream and 1 egg and then combined it with the ziti.  Used 1/2 lb hamburger and 1/2 lb mild Italian sausage.  Spread sauce on the bottom of the pan, eliminating butter or oil, left out provolone cheese.  Layered sauce, ziti-ricotta cheese mixture, sprinkle of Italian herbs, 1/2 c of mozzarella cheese, repeated the layers, topped with a layer of sauce, shredded mozzarella and slices of fresh mozzarella on top.  Baked covered for 30 min, then uncovered for another 15 min.  Delish!

text:
i have made this recipe several times, over the years and absolutely love sour cream instead of ricotta.  there is no such thing as "more italian" as one reviewer suggested.  over the years i have substituted sour cream for ricotta and it is actually better and not so bland. As for covering it, thats just common sense.  I have fussy eaters and this is sure to please. its guaranteed to be all gone with no leftovers.  
i dont usually write reviews but the dumb bad reviews, sparked me to write this. taking away 2 stars cause you didnt have common sense to cover it is ridiculous and you dont give a rating unless you made it.
I have also made it and froze it before baking for a great ready to bake meal.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/2585283.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great easy-to-make dish! I read a number of reviews and made the following adjustments: use a large 9x13 casserole dish and add 1-3 cloves of garlic to meat and onion while browning, and use a high quality pasta sauce.  I use penne pasta because I have not seen ziti here yet, and I found using a shredded mozzarella/provolone/Parmesan cheese mix a real time saver. I mixed the pasta and sauce as one layer, and also use light sour cream as this is a very high fat dish already. Covered with aluminum foil which is removed at the end and broiled for 2 min to brown on the top. A keeper!

text:
5 stars. Amazing. I used some tips in the reviews cause it sounded like I’d like it better. So I used 16oz of ricotta instead of sour cream, added one egg to the ricotta and then I mixed this into the cooked pasta noodles (I use penne cause that’s easier for me to find) so that way they’re all evenly coated with the ricotta/egg mix. I use closer to 2lbs of ground beef because my husband like it’s really meaty. The other thing I do it I use only mozzarella cheese cause I don’t love provolone, I grate a little bit of fresh Parmesan reggiano between the layers.

text:
Been using this recipe for years, always a hit in our family! We only use mild or hot Italian sausage, not ground beef. Once the pasta is cooked and drained, I mix the pasta and the sour cream together in the same pot I cooked the pasta in, then put 1/2 if it into the baking pan in order to ensure all the sour cream is evenly distributed. Other than that I follow the recipe as instructed and add a little more sauce, if needed.

23502907
Display Name:
Rebecca Sikes Bauer
isPro:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5252663.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great meal for a cold night and a big group! Here are the changes I made - I used Rigatoni instead of Ziti - I used a tub of cottage cheese in place of the sour cream, mixed that together with one egg and 1 cup of shredded “pizza blend” cheese - cooked diced onion, garlic & a shredded carrot in olive oil and then added a jar of pasta sauce, a can of crushed tomatoes, oregano, parsley, onion powder and basil - spread 1 cup of sauce on bottom of pan, then a layer of drained noodles, a layer of the cheese mixture (kinda plop blobs of it on top and spread as best you can with a rubber spatula) a layer of sauce, the rest of the noodles, the rest of the cheese mixture and then make sure there is sauce all the way around the edges so the noodles don’t get dried out.

None
text:
My daughter is not a big ricotta cheese fan so I decided to try this recipe and I am so happy that I did! Everyone loved it! The only things I changed was that I substituted sweet sausage for the ground beef and I added minced garlic and Italian seasoning to the sausage and onion while it was cooking. I also mixed the ziti with the sauce mixture before adding it to the baking dish. great recipe. I made it the day before and refrigerated it, so I let it sit out for 30 minutes,  baked it covered for 1 hour, removed the cover to let the mozzarella melt, baked it for another 15 minutes, then let stand for 15 minutes. It needed all that extra time.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614262.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I've been making this regularly for several years now, and it's always wonderful. It's a very friendly recipe to those of us that don't enjoy cooking and aren't all that great at it either.  I don't add the onions, I cut the sour cream quantity in half, and I use a little extra mozzarella, otherwise I use this recipe as written. I often mix up the brand and flavor of jar spaghetti sauce I use to get a little different taste. It's always a huge family favorite! Some people suggest using ricotta, but my family does not enjoy ricotta, so we use the sliced provolone. Also, some people insist that you must cover this dish or else it dries out...I've made this at least 30 times and it has never dried out; I would suggest those people are only using 1 (26 oz) jar of sauce instead of 2 as the recipe calls for.  If you prepare this ahead and refrigerate it before cooking, it will take 45 to 60 minutes to heat all the way through, so that is the only time you need to cover the top.

text:
I made this last night and it turned out great.  It's just my husband and me, so I made a half recipe.  I did what one other reviewer did...I mixed sour cream and ricotta together... yummy! I also didn't see that it called for Provolone, until I was making it. I had two slices, so I used those plus mozzarella slices. This is a great base recipe for any sauce. I had leftover homemade so I mixed that with the jar sauce I had.  This an easy one to do. I want sure how it would do not mixed altogether but it was moist and cheesy!! Just the way we like it  great recipe!! Thanks!!!

text:
I made this recipe different  because I only had certain things on hand. I made it the way I would typically make baked penne, in terms of seasonings, canned tomatoes/sauce, and using ground up sausage. I used shredded cheese for both cheese layers. I was intrigued by the sour cream option as I had some leftover and wanted to use it. It came okay. It didn't dry out but it tasted different. The sour cream seemed good, but awkward. You could tell it was not ricotta and your taste buds were like, wait a minute.... It was an interesting change and I'll eat the leftovers 
 but I likely won't make it again.

text:
This truly is a great easy peasy recipe.  One just has to remember to season the meat.  I seasoned my meat with garlic salt, Italian seasoning and red pepper.  Garlic (fresh or powdered) is a must! Make sure to season the meat for a flavor boost.  I also agree with other reviewers who covered the dish to ensure the noodles don't get crunchy.  I also just baked for 20-25min.  It's more than enough time to get the cheese melty.

country:
None
text:
It’s now my go-to ziti recipe. Have made it about 4 times now. I do- make pasta and mix with the sauce in the first layer. I also put the sour cream in a baggie and cut  off the corner to make the spreading easier (helps if sour cream isn’t right out of fridge.) Then mix the second batch of ziti with the sauce for top layer. Add more sauce than you think you will need. It does dry while cooking, even though I foil it and then broil last 5 minutes (without foil) to be nice and bubbly.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/40384.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family loves this recipe. Made this as written originally, and then made a few changes. The layers (and the effort) were not appreciated, and I have toddlers and they need homogeneity.  So to make it easier, I cook the carrots (love that they're hidden in here), onions and 20 oz ground turkey together, then mix with the spaghetti sauce, mozzarella, 24 ounces cottage cheese (I loved the sour cream but wanted extra protein for the kids) and elbows (easier for toddlers). I can't bear to use 3/4 of a package of mozzarella, so I use the entire 8 ounces.  Pour in half into the baking dish, layer the provolone (love this), and then pour the other half. It makes so much and is so comforting, and doing it this way makes it SO MUCH FASTER which is great for busy moms. I always worry that there will be too much sauce but I swear it works out perfectly every time. I didn't have any problems with drying out (it's only 30 minutes for a full to the brim baking dish), or sticking - I used parchment paper or aluminum foil which is totally nonstick.

text:
Amazing! This would also taste outstanding in the original form, too, but I just made a few changes due to what I had on hand.  I used 1 lb grd. turkey and I used 1 cup Ricotta cheese and 1 cup sour cream blended together. I ACCIDENTALLY omitted the mozzarella cheese...I just noticed that now, but no need for it with the provolone slices. I also layered differently with a cup of sauce on the bottom first, then noodles, then provolone slices, ricotta/sour cream, sauce again...and continue from there in same order with sauce  and then the Parmesan over the top.  There was plenty of sauce for all of that!  My 16 yr. old son ate 2 big helpings.  Also, because my 3 girls are at college, I made the whole recipe but divided it between two casserole dishes and froze one for another meal.  Definitely try this!

text:
This was yummy. My family had mixed feelings about it but my toddler seemed to love it. The only things I changed was the order of the layers. Like others suggested, I covered the ziti in the sauce then layered the cheese and sour cream. I also did half ground beef and half mild Italian sausage, which I seasoned with salt & pepper.

It made a lot, it fully filled a glass 11x17in baking dish and some sauce bubbled out onto the oven floor but I did not have to prepare a second dish for it, the one 11x17 was enough as the recipe states. I think our family of 5 could eat from this 1 meal, 3 times. I could see making this for company or a sick friend, etc.

Thanks for sharing a great meal!

I didn't make any changes except make some Italian mild sausages and slice them and add them to the first layer because my kid kept asking for me to make my spaghetti and sausages, but iit takes so long, but she really wanted the Italian sausages. text:
Overall a good recipe, but I found that adding a few things to the sauce really brought out the flavour. I added some fresh basil and oregano to the sauce, and added an extra ounce of mozzarella cheese. Following the advice of other reviewers, I changed up the layering of the dish. I mixed the ziti with the sauce and spread it first, layered the provolone, sour cream, ziti with sauce again, then mozzarella to top.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I have made a lot of baked ziti in the past, using ricotta and egg, but thought I’d give this a try, since the ratings were so good. I doubled the recipe and made a pan to bring to a friend recovering from surgery and her family. The other half stayed with my family. I used a pound of lean ground beef and a pound of sweet Italian sausage, rather than doubling the beef. I also added 2 cloves of crushed fresh garlic and some Italian seasoning. I baked it covered in foil, as suggested by other cooks. It stayed nice and moist. I was intrigued by the sour cream, but also a little unsure of how it would taste. It was a hit! My picky family loved it and my friend said she and her family loved it too!

text:
Just made this a couple days ago for a party and already getting asked for the recipe by guests. I made this without any meat since we had some vegetarians attending. Which actually made it so much easier. I cooked the pasta, put it in the dish and just opened the jar of pasta sauce and poured it right on the pasta, then I did the cheese/ sour cream layer, pasta with sauce again and mozzarella and Parm on top. Was so simple and delicious. Definitely recommend keeping the sour cream and not switching this recipe. Thanks for sharing - it was enjoyed by many!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe was fabulous, and it was super easy!  I didn't have ziti noodles so I used some rotini that I had on hand. I also added three large Anaheim peppers to the onions because I had them on hand and needed to use them up. They were a really nice touch! I used 2 lbs. of ground beef and since I only had one large 32 oz. jar of marinara, I added a can of tomato sauce and a can of diced tomatoes.  Then I added some Italian seasoning, garlic, and some red pepper flakes.  I also didn't have provolone so I used the shredded mozzarella I had on hand. This is a fail-proof recipe, because you can play around with it and it'll be awesome. DO use the sour cream -- it really makes it special! Super glad that I found this and I'll definitely make it often.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
This dish was a great hit!! Even the picky eater had seconds. I only did a few modifications for my liking as follows: double meat - one pound ground beef, one lb ground mild Italian sausage. I added Italian seasoning to the jar sauce and let it slow simmer while I prepared everything else. Instead of having all the cheesy layers, I took the sour cream / ricotta and put 3/4 cup of each and stirred into the sauce. I tossed together the noodles, meat & onion, & sauce in a large mixing bowl with shredded Parmesan and Mozzarella (I don’t measure my cheese. FYI. ??.) I spooned the mix in 3 layers with the sliced provolone between each layer in a large stoneware baking bowl. Covered and baked until warm in center. Removed foil, added cheese on top and broiled to add a nice cheese crust. Mouth watering good.

text:
This is a new staple in my meal rotation. I’ve made it three times already (once a month for the past three months) and my family of three LOVES it.  It also makes TONS of leftovers which is great because of my work schedule. After I make it, I know there is something in the fridge my hubby can warm up for him and my daughter if I’m working late.

 The only changes I made was I used two 24 oz jars of sauce because I couldn’t find any 26 oz jars in my grocery store. I also didn’t use Ziti, I prefer using Rotini instead because it picks up more of the sauce and cheese. And I’ve tried different sauces each time to make it a little different. I think our favorite is Ragú Chunky 7 Herb Tomato.

text:
I was really happy with how this turned out. I followed some of the tips from the top reviews: add some of the sauce before the first layer of cheese, mix the sauce into the noodles some on both layers, and cover with foil while baking. I substituted Edam cheese for provolone, which I wasn't able to find in my UK supermarket. I also used slightly less sour cream: 300 ml instead of a 1.5 cups, which would have been 360 ml. That was just because of the size of the sour cream containers here, but it worked fine. The pan was completely full as it was.

text:
I've made this recipe several times and it is delicious. Ricotta cheese can also be used in lieu of the sour cream.  I serve it with a tomato, cucumber and onion salad, which is light and refreshing.  So yummy!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674160.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This came out really good and creamy. However, instead of layering the ingredients separately, I combined the noodles with most of the sauce, sour cream and meat together. Then I poured half the noodle mixture in the pan, topped that with the shredded mozzarella and provolone cheeses, then poured the second half of the noodle mixture, topped it with the provolone, the rest of the sauce, then covered it and baked it for about half an hour. After that, I uncovered the dish, topped it with the rest of the mozzarella and Parmesan cheeses and then baked again for another 10 minutes until the cheese melted. My family loved it.

Ok I totally agree with Bayou Gator on this one. This recipe is amazing. If your gonna completely change it, than submit your own baked ziti recipe and leave this one be. I made this recipe this weekend and it was a huge hit! My Mother-in law who is a huge food critic informed me it was by far the best ziti she has ever had! I did simmer the sauce with my own fresh herbs from our garden, and added a few tablespoons of ricotta to the sour cream, only because I like that consistency... it was delicious. Fantastic recipe. Thanks for sharing this Colleen!
PS. I did not have to cover this... no need, and I made mine in a dutch oven (without the lid)

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this for my family last night and we liked this quite well. I, too, was skeptical about using provolone and sour cream in it, but the combination of those with mozzarella and parmesan on top did result in a pleasant, cheesy taste. I made it per the recipe, but used my own sauce (no recipe for that--a few cans of tomato sauce, a can of diced tomatoes, some of this and that...) and had to use gluten-free penne. The GF penne, as expected, somewhat disintegrated, so next time I think I'll only partially cook it and hopefully it will complete cooking in the oven. Leftovers, although rather formless due to the GF pasta, tasted even better today for lunch! I will make this for a dinner for our Bible study coming up--I'm glad I tested it on my family first, so I will be able to serve it to other people confidently!

text:
i made this in a pinch without the provolone,  and it was still very good. I can't wait to try it with the provolone included.  Like many others, I made slight changes. I added a few spices, and I mixed the pasta and the sauce before layering.  I also mixed Italian sausage and garlic into the sauce. It  didn't seem like 350 was getting  the job done, so I bumped the temp up to 400 for the last 10 minutes.  Other than that, I baked uncovered for the last 5 minutes or so to crisp up the top a bit. I like the browned cheese and the firm/crunchy bits. I halved the recipe, and it was still a lot of food.

The only change I made was combining the sauce and noodles and then follow the rest of the recipe it was less dry and all the noodles were covered. Family asked me to make it that way every time. text:
I liked this recipe but I did make a few changes. I didn't use provolone because I didn't have any, so it was all mozzarella. I layered it differently: mix half the sauce with half the ziti, combine the cheese with sour cream and spread over bottom layer, mix a little of the remaining sauce with the rest of the ziti (just enough to coat the pasta), pour the last of the sauce over dish and cover with cheese. Also, make sure to cover the dish with foil. Next time, I'll try replacing the sour cream with ricotta cheese, as some reviewers suggested. The sour cream was a little overpowering.

text:
This was a great recipe, the bf had 3 helpings! I made some changes based on the highest rated review, I mixed two eggs with ricotta cheese (added handful Italian cheese blend of Parmesan asiago etc) then added the al dente ziti. I used 1 lb mild Italian sausage with onion and half bulb of garlic, adding generous pepper, chili pepper flakes, garlic powder, onion powder, dried basil, oregano, and a large spoon of white sugar. As for layers I went two times over with: sauce, ziti/ricotta mix, shredded mozzarella, Parmesan asiago mix cheese, sprinkle of basil and oregano.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
This ended up being a pleasant surprise even though I was missing one crucial ingredient:  ZITI! I used Penne because it was all I had  (I swore that I had ziti shells).  I question whether the sauce amount is a typo as all of the sauces were 24 Oz. not 26. I used 1 jar of garlic and olive oil,  1 jar of sausage flavored, and only deviated from the recipe by adding 1 clove of minced garlic and a 4 cheese shredded Italian mixture instead of just mozzarella. I  did read the reviews and my thoughts on using Ricotta instead of sour cream  are that you might as well just make a pan of lasagna if you use the Ricotta. The sour cream added an extra depth to this superb recipe. And yes,  you need to cover it with aluminum foil while baking.  I covered mine for 20 minutes and then uncovered for 10 to brown the top. I got rave reviews and have already been asked to make it again very soon!

I roughly made a double batch of this. I say roughly because I didn't follow the ingredient amounts too closely, but I still followed the recipe. I found it was good, but took a bit longer to prep and cook than the recipe says. The pasta sauce that you buy is also very important, so don't skimp out on it. I added about 7 cloves of garlic and also some extra onion and Italian seasoning to give some extra 'oomph'. I also switched up the layers and put a mixture of noodles and sauce on the bottom which I would do again. I also cooked the pan covered in tinfoil.

text:
Everyone in the family enjoyed this.  I used a slightly bigger casserole dish, so I doubled meat.  Used 2lbs of ground turkey, added 3 cloves of minced garlic.  Seasoned turkey well with salt, pepper, and Italian seasonings due to turkey not being as flavorful as beef. When meat/sauce was done simmering, I tossed slightly undercooked ziti into pan and coated noodles well with sauce mixture, then I layered as directions stated. Used 9 thin slices of provolone (due to bigger casserole dish).  Cooked closer to 45-50 min.  About 45 min covered, 5 min uncovered.

text:
This dish is AMAZING! My boyfriend and I love it and there's always enough left overs for a few nights and when you reheat it, it's still just as good! The things I do differently are: 
1) I add a clove of minced garlic when I brown the onions.
2) I mix my pasta and sauce together.
3) cover with tin foil so the pasta doesn't dry
4) once the cheese is melted, I take the foil off and broil till cheese is golden brown!

So glad I found this recipe!(:

As with every recipe, I have to alter to accommodate my vegetarian husband.  I cut the recipe in one-half, as there are only the 2 of us.  I used one can of Loma Linda vegetarian ground beef, and took another reviewer's recommendation of ricotta--good suggestion.  It came out really good.  I also added a couple of tablespoons of olive oil to avoid dryness, due to the lack of fat that I would have gotten from the hamburger.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I substituted the spaghetti meat sauce with the sauce from John Chandler's World's Best Lasagna. After I drained the ziti, I put them back into the pot, added the sauce and a handful of Italian blend shredded cheese and stirred until combined. I put a bit of sauce on the bottom of the baking dish and then added half the pasta mixture. Topped that with the sliced provolone. Thin layer of sour cream. Then the rest of the pasta mixture. Topped the dish with a good amount of the shredded cheese and Parmesan cheese. Baked covered 350F for 30 minutes. Removed the foil and broiled for a couple of minutes.  Delicious!

text:
I made this as a side dish for our family Christmas, and it was delicious.  Loved the sour cream in place of ricotta.  Our main dish was beef tenderloin, so I made a version of this with roasted vegetables.  I cut zucchini, summer squash, onions, mushrooms and eggplant into bite-sized pieces and coated them in about 1 tablespoon of extra virgin olive oil.  Added salt and pepper and roasted in a hot oven at 425 degrees until their were some charred bits.  I layered the vegetables in place of the ground beef.  Seriously delicious.

Everyone in my family was given one request for our Thanksgiving dinner menu. My husband chose baked ziti. I followed some advice in the other reviews and substituted 1 lb of ricotta with one beaten egg for the sour cream. I also used mozzarella instead of provolone. I will absolutely make this dish again. Next time I will add more meat, either ground beef or sausage. We like our sauce a little more meaty than the recipe came out. Also, this recipe makes a HUGE pan of pasta. We will have leftovers for a while, and that's a good thing!

text:
What I loved about this recipe is that it is simple and quick to make.  I made a few small changes that in my opinion improved the dish. Substituted 3/4 cup sour cream & 3/4 cup cottage cheese for the 1 1/2 cups sour cream the recipe calls for. I increased the sauce volume by 4 oz's. Increased garlic to 3 cloves. Added fennel seed while simmering the sauce & meat. Baked covered with foil until the last 5 minutes and uncovered it and lightly browned the top under the broiler.

text:
I know no one wants to hear changes to the original recipes but I personally enjoy reading things cooks did to improve or alter a recipe! I've made this exactly as written several times and it's delicious (as long as it's covered so not to dry out).
I didn't have sour cream nor provolone cheese so I made this using a shredded sharp cheese in place of provolone and cottage cheese in place of sour cream... I even used a different spiral pasta... otherwise followed the recipe exactly and it was amazingly good!  It had a bit more of a lasagna flare but delicious as well.  I just wanted to share this in case anyone didn't have the exact ingredients on hand... it's very adaptable.  Thanks for a fast easy good recipe!

text:
Wow this dish was awesome! I was a little confused why it had such high ratings yet so many reviews switched out so many ingredients it basically became a different recipe... I made it exactly as listed and it came out perfect! Reading the ingredients you can tell it's not a traditional style Italian dish, so don't expect it to taste like  Nonna's ziti with her homemade sauce. It's still fantastic, just in a different way. This was a huge hit with my husband who isn't a big fan of ricotta, which I know to be a staple in many Italian dishes, so it was so nice to find this cheesy, creamy and meaty dish without the ricotta! All in all at a quick, easy and delicious dish that will be a hit with picky eaters.

userID:
14947858
Display Name:
Sara
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
32
favoritesCount:
302
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674159.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is the second time I've made this dish. Both times,  I used mostaccioli instead of ziti, just because I like it better. 
The first time,  I didn't change anything except for the kind of noodles used,  and the family loved it.  We ate the whole dish within 24 hours. (3 people)  
This second time, I divided the ingredients into two baking dishes,  which was definitely a good idea.  I liked that it had lots of cheese and topping along with the noodles. 
I got 72 ounces of sauce rather than 52, and I used every bit of it. I spread it on the bottom of the baking dishes so that the noodles wouldn't stick, as well as mixing it in with the noodles as soon as they were drained, before layering them in the baking dish. 
For the sauce,  I used the meat and onions, but I also added a can of mushrooms.  I will probably add three cans of mushrooms next time. (Drained and dried) 
I would not substitute ricotta for the sour cream,  as I love the way the sour cream tastes in this recipe and the way it cooks up.  I even added slightly more sour cream this second time that I made it. 
As I divided the meal between two dishes, I added spinach to the second,  smaller dish. This one was favored over the other. 
How I layered: small amount of sauce in bottom, ziti/sauce mixture, more sauce (so that ziti doesn't dry out), provolone, sour cream, (then the spinach for one dish), ziti/sauce mixture, sauce, mozzarella, sauce, parmesan. 
Cover for the first 30 minutes of baking.
Review:

5

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good recipe, but if you're picky about Italian food you will want to add fresh basil, fresh rosemary, and crushed red pepper to the sauce. Also, coarse ground black pepper, and 2 tsp of sugar. It will make a big difference.

I made the mistake of adding 1lb of Italian sausage to the sauce after reading reviews that suggested it -- don't do it -- go with either 1lb of ground beef OR 1lb of sausage, or half pound of each. 2lbs of meat is too much for this recipe.

Really wasn't sure about the sour cream and provolone. It wasn't bad, but I think the ricotta/parmesan/egg mixture that goes in a traditional lasagna would have been better.

Will definitely make it again, with the above changes!

text:
Before making this recipe, I took a look at the reviews to see what changes others have made. The idea of sour cream did not sound appetizing to me, personally. 

I took LP's review and used it to make this recipe. The Baked Ziti tastes absolutely better with ricotta instead of sour cream. Adding the egg to the ricotta before mixing with the pasta adds more creaminess to the dish. Next time I make this dish I'll be cutting the recipe in half since theres only 2 people in my house. The 1X recipe of Baked Ziti lasted us a very long time!

text:
What a great recipe!  I didn't notice the taste of the sour cream at all!  The only thing I did differently was use ground pork since I don't eat beef.  And I followed what everyone else said about adding the sauce first, mixing the noodles with the sauce, and then layering it with the cheese/sour cream combo and so on.  I also added garlic, oregano, basil, onion powder, salt, and pepper to the ground pork as it was cooking. Cooking it covered, but uncovering it the last 5 or less mins to broil the cheese on top.

But these are all just minor details that don't really change the recipe by much.  The recipe will taste good as is!  My husband said it's the best baked ziti he's ever had!
