This is one of the first recipes I made from the original cookbook years ago. The ONLY modification from this original recipe that HAS to be done is sauce in the dish before you start. If you only bake it 30 minutes, it shouldn't dry out, but anything with cheese on top, I typically cover. Over the years I have mixed the sauce and noodles together before assembling, added mini pepperoni on top with the cheese, added meatballs to the sauce, swapped out ricotta for the sour cream & provolone and all ways were wonderful. This is a Hall of fame dish. I've been making it since 2002. It's also awesome as a plan ahead dish, assemble and cover with parchment paper under the foil and freeze. Thaw out and bake. Thanks Colleen!

country:

text:
As is, the sauce seemed  naked. I added 1/2 minced red bell pepper, 4 cloves of minced garlic, and sweated the onions , garlic abd red bell pepper in olive oil. After 10 minutes I removed the vegetables and browned a small can of organic tomato paste in a touch of olive oil(low heat) for 5 minutes, then added the vegetables to the sauce to intensify and fuse the paste for snother 5 minutes. I added the pasta sauce, using a good quality, organic, low sodium sauce, the browned ground beef, seasoned only with fresh black pepper draining the fat before adding to the gravy.  plus 1 cup of red wine, a tablespoon of sugar and about 7-8 good size fresh Pennsylvania white mushrooms thinly sliced. Simmer 90 minutes. I make the gravy the night before and refrigerate it overnight, reheating the gravy the next day until bubbly (about an hour.) However, you can assemble without the extra step of cooling then refrigerating overnight.  You can skip this step

Substitute the sour cream fot 16oz of ricotta mixed with one egg and 1/4 tsp of garlic powder.
Prepare the  ziti pasta (I don't salt it). Mix the ricotta with the cooked. Strsin pasta.
After spraying a deep 13x9 with non-stick spray, put 1/3 of the gravy on the bottom, add 1/2 pasta, add 1/3gravy then cheeses. Repeat. Civer and bake for 35-40min, remove foil and bake another 5-10 min. Remove from oven and allow tp sit 20minutes before serving

text:
Instead of sour cream, I used a ricotta mixture containing ricotta, salt, parsley and one egg. Also used sliced cheese instead of shredded and changed the order of the layers with the top layer being the sliced mozzarella to which I added grated Parmesan, garlic powder and some Italian seasoning.  Only other additions/changes I made were to the meat sauce. I used 2 lbs and added mushrooms and 2 cloves of garlic along with oregano, parsley and salt then simmered for 2hrs. I baked the dish for 30 mins covered and then again uncovered until it was golden brown. turned out very hearty and delicious.

text:
I took advice from the reviews & made a few changes of my own.  First, I mixed 15 ounces ricotta cheese with 4 ounces sour cream & an egg, & then I mixed in the ziti.  When browning the onions & beef, I added 1 teaspoon garlic salt, 1/2 teaspoon fresh black pepper, & 1 teaspoon dried garlic before adding the sauce.  I greased the pan with butter & layered in the following order: sauce, ziti, shredded mozzarella, dried basil, sauce, ziti, dried basil, sliced mozzarella.  Notice I completely left out the provolone.  The sliced mozzarella on top gave it a nice clean look, & it was absolutely delicious with the changes!

country:
None
text:
I  made the recipe as written the first time I made.  My family loved it;  I thought it was good.  The 2nd time, I used italian sausage instead of ground beef and ricotta instead of sour cream.   Fantastic!   The trick to these types of recipes, IMHO, is to be sure to use a pasta sauce that you like.  It can be your own or store bought as long as you like it  & make sure that your pasta is a bit undercooked when you drain it.  Do not rinse the pasta. 
Unless you made this ahead and refrigerated or froze it,  it shouldn't require a cover when baking.  If you did refrigerate it,  cover it for @ 30 minutes  then remove cover to allow cheese to brown while it finishes cooking. 
It makes a lot and I  usually freeze half for another meal.

This was a hit! I made it for the first time as a take-along dish for my niece's graduation party - a gutsy call - but it worked out.  It was a smash.  I made it again the next day for my own family and they loved it too.  Don't let the non-traditional ingredients like sour cream and provolone throw you. This is the best and I will continue using the recipe. I did make some changes based on other reviewers. I covered the meal so it wouldn't dry out. I covered the ziti with the sauce between layers and at the bottom. I was skeptical about using sour cream but it was awesome. I used light sour cream and I added extra cheese. I had leftovers and froze sections enough for two people. I used tin foil and a zip lock. We've already had one section - I baked in the tin foil on a pan in the convection oven.  For me , it took about 40-45 minutes to warm from frozen and it was still awesome!  Thank you for sharing!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Homemade Sauce instead of canned. Try "World's Best Spaghetti Sauce" with ground chicken and ground sweet Italian chicken sausage instead of beef and pork. Add an additional tsp of salt, fresh rosemary, fresh basil, red wine instead of water, triple the garlic. If you're lazy, place everything on low in a crockpot for five hours after you've browned the meat. As for this recipe, halve the sour cream and replace the other half with ricotta. Mix the sour cream and ricotta into the noodles (it will look like white sauce) and add freshly chopped parsley. To assemble: 1/2 noodles, 1/2 cheese (I also add mozzarella and Parmesan), 1/2 sauce. This will make two layers. Bake covered in aluminum until the last ten minutes.

text:
An easy and delicious recipe.  The only change I made was to delete the Provolone, and use grated Parmesan cheese.  I've made it three times and twice I used my own sauce (that which I had made) instead of jarred, but the jarred sauce works well, too.  The nice thing is that it can be made in advance and frozen.  I did this for a party last year where I did half of the cooking (the other half was Chipotle catering), and it was a big hit, not only with the adults, but with the teenagers who attended.  To me, that always says a lot about a recipe (when a teenager is impressed).

My husband went crazy for this baked ziti!! I honestly didn't miss the ricotta at all. I followed the recipe exactly, except I used a little less pasta because I like a lot of sauce, and I also added garlic because we are garlic lovers. I followed another reviewer's tip to use Classico Sausage and Pepper sauce and I'm so glad I did. It had tremendous flavor without having to bother using half sausage and half ground beef. You could try any variety of sauces with this recipe and it would still taste fantastic. The only thing my husband requested for next time I make this was to add mushrooms.

text:
Made a few changes & it turned out great!

Used 2 28oz cans of cento crushed tomatoes instead of pasta sauce , added 2 cloves of garlic to the onions just before adding the beef.  2 Tbs of chopped basil just before adding the tomato sauce.  Then used nonfat greek yogurt instead of the sour cream and Romano instead of Parmesan on top. Finally, olive oil to coat the pan instead of butter. 

My 8 year old son...who usually just wants mac & cheese or chicken nuggets...asked if he could have it again for dinner tomorrow night! That's a WIN

text:
Delicious!!  I used a penne pasta (I used a pretty good quality pasta that I bought at Nugget Market).  I put a layer of sauce on the bottom of the pan, then pasta, more sauce, then sour cream and I also used some ricotta cheese, provolone and mozzarella.  Then another layer of pasta, more sauce, more provolone and mozzarella on top and a generous topping of parmesan cheese.  Doubled the recipe for a group of 12 and baked it about 80 minutes at 375 degrees, then removed the foil and browned the top for about 10 min more.  Sooooooo good!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I looked at multiple recipes and reviews trying to tweak it using this recipe as a primary base.

I broke down the 1 1/2 cups of sour creme to 3/4 a cup of sour cream and ricotta which was well worth it. there was enough creaminess from the sour cream while letting the ricotta stand out on top (yet still not overpowering).

Of the 3 times I have made the recipe I used regular ground beef twice and ground Italian sausage once. If you can, I highly recommend getting some Italian sausage, you can still season the meat (more below) but the sausage added much more robust flavor. In terms of the meat, as I cook it I add a little rosemary, fresh chopped basil, Italian seasoning, thyme, and minced garlic which helps really add some depth to the meat and dish.

Finally I personally recommend cooking it covered for 30 min before then cooking it uncovered for an extra 15. Its better to then let it rest for maybe 10 min or so to let it keep form better, but not required if you or the people your feeding are hungry :)

4

text:
I got rave reviews on this - from both the in-laws and my husband! I can't do beef, so I used ground turkey. I followed other reviews and put garlic in with the meat while browning. I also seasoned the turkey with a fair amount of salt and pepper, just to get it to taste like something;). I made it with penne pasta noodles, which worked great. I also followed what other reviewers said and layered as follows: noodles, sauce, sour cream, provolone, noodles, sauce and mozzarella.  It makes a lot, but it all fit in my 9 x 13 dish. You just need to have a deeper 9 x 13, because it builds up tall once you finish your layers. There were four adults eating hearty portions and we still had over half the dish for leftovers. Big hit!

This is great.  I can never find ziti at my store so I use penne and my daughter loves it.  The sour cream is a must, but I've tried this without the provolone and I can't tell the difference at all. Saves me 3 bucks.  I also don't use onions or meat in it.  It's great without as well.

text:
I love, love, love this recipe!  It's a staple for me to make for potlucks or anywhere I need to take a main dish.  It's fairly quick to prepare and I keep most of the ingredients on hand, so I have to do minimal shopping.  I changed the way I layer it based on another review; I mix the ziti (or penne) with the sauce, then add provolone, sour cream and the next layer of ziti with sauce, then the mozzarella and Parmesan.  It's always a hit and I pass the link to the recipe out every time I make it!

I made this tonight and followed the recipe exactly as written. It was very good as written. This recipe exceeded my expectations. I wanted to alter it as I made it because I was fairly sure it wouldn't be that great but I fought the urge and made it as written. It was easy, quick, budget-friendly, and it made a lot. I halved the recipe and it could've easily still fed 4-6 people. And it tasted very good. Next time I will make the full recipe and freeze half. Will definitely make again.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1100720.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Let me just explain to you how good this recipe is.  I've made this at least 50 times so far over the last 4 or 5 years.  And not because I want to, but because it is requested for family, friend, or work functions and even by my 6 year-old son and fiance for family dinner.  I've made it just as the recipe specifies except subbing ground turkey for the ground beef, and it's really good.  

Over the years, however, I've tweaked it a bit.  Now I make it using ground turkey and turkey Italian sausage in the sauce, browning that with garlic, onion, and green pepper (and sometimes a little cayenne pepper).  I put a thin layer of sauce on the bottom of the baking dish before putting in the first layer of noodles and mix it up to coat the noodles with sauce.  I use Greek yogurt instead of the sour cream, and I use way more of it, maybe 1 1/2 cups to get a thick layer over the provolone.   I use nearly the whole bag of parmesan cheese on top.  It's a winner.

country:

text:
We loved this! We were craving lasagna but didn't want to put that much work in, this was perfect! I used a pound each of ground beef and Italian sausage. I added some garlic powder, Italian seasoning, and mrs dash to the meat sauce combo. After reading other reviews, I decided to mix the pasta with the meat sauce before layering as the recipe states. We like it really cheesy so I used about double the amount of mozzarella and instead skipped out on the Parmesan. I used a 9x15 in pan and it fit perfect. Covered with foil for about 40 min and uncovered for about 10 min. I will definitely be making this again. It was so easy, inexpensive, and incredibly delicious!

text:
Best Baked Ziti I've ever made!!!... 
Although I was taken aback by sour cream as an ingredient, I challenged myself dislikes and added it anyhow. I'm so glad I did.

Typical of me, I did tweek the recipe a bit by substituting red meat with ground turkey meat. I then seasoned both turkey meat and sauce with a variety of seasonings, such as garlic, pepper, sazón, caraway seeds, Italian herbs, parsley and dark brown sugar. Other than that, I stuck to the recipe and it was FANTASTIC!!!!  Que Rico!!!

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I am Italian and actually love ricotta cheese, but my family does not.  So I was pretty excited to find a baked ziti recipe with an alternative to the ricotta component.  I pretty much followed the recipe exactly, except for the fact that I made a vegetarian version, subbing some zucchini and mushrooms for the meat.  And I did follow the advice of others about putting the sauce layer on top of the penne before the cheeses.

The outcome?  Well, I liked it, and thought it was a nice change from traditional baked ziti. It was very tasty and light.  I don't think it is better than the old stand-by, but still very good.  My teenage daughter loved it, and ate 3 helpings.  My son wouldn't touch it, but he doesn't like tomato sauce, and my spouse thought the sour cream gave it a strange taste.  

So there you have it.  It's a mixed review, but largely positive, and I'm glad I tried it!  Looking forward to the leftovers for lunch tomorrow...

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I took the advice of the others and used a small tub of ricotta cheese with an egg mixed in (instead of sour cream), added some Italian herbs to the sauce, layered the dish as follows: sauce--> noodles--> ricotta cheese mix--> sauce--> provolone cheese slices --> noodles --> sauce --> shredded mozzarella.  I baked it for 30 min covered with tin foil, put a little more mozzarella cheese on the top and baked it for another 10 minutes to get bubbly and ever so slightly browned.  Let it rest for 5 minutes or you'll melt your face off.

To quote my finicky seven year old, "I don't like this Dad, I LOVE it.  Can we have this tomorrow too?"

text:
I made a variation of this. Sautee in olive oil 1 each green, red, and yellow pepper, one medium size onion, and two cloves garlic. add 1 lb ground hot Italian sausage. cook on medium heat until sausage is cooked through. add a dash of pepper to taste. boil ziti. mix ricotta with pasta sauce. layer pasta, sauce,  meat mixture, and mozzarella cheese in casserole.  top with mozzarella cheese. bake in oven until bubbly.

text:
I've made this recipe twice, and it's so delicious. I was hesitant at first using the sour cream, but I wasn't disappointed at all. I use the entire 16 ounces of sour cream, 8 oz. bag of mozzarella cheese, and 1/2 lb of sliced mozzarella. I also add 1 tsp each of oregano, parsley, and garlic. I would also cover it next time, and add a little extra sauce.

country:
None
text:
This is a GREAT recipe! It's also super easy to throw together. I deducted a star because I think the recipe calls for way too much onion. I used half of an onion and it was still way too much. My boyfriend said I should leave it out because it "doesnt do anything for the dish". So if you aren't huge on onion I recommend not putting any at all. The recipe is also way too much for a 9x13 dish. I had about a third of the noodles left over and my dish was filled to the rim. The great thing about this recipe is you can add as much or little cheese and sauce as desired. This is an awesome dish. My boyfriend and I ate on it all day and finished it, too.

country:

text:
All I can say is this is a hit.  Possibly the best thing I've ever made from this site.  Everyone was pleased! 

I made this for a potluck...on the wrong day.  I was wondering what I was going to do with sooooo much food left, but I didn't need to worry.  This was all but gone the very next day!

I made a few changes based on what I had and my energy level (I'm currently 5 1/2 months pregnant, so energy is a commodity these days).  
*Use 1 lb ground turkey
*brown 1 (orange) bell pepper and 1 small onion with the turkey...season the meat with seasoned salt, garlic powder, and black pepper to taste.
*mix 8oz sour cream w/ 8oz Philadelphia Garden Vegetable spread (I was not about to measure the sour cream and the cream cheese adds a lot of flavor).

text:
Very tasty and very easy.  I thought it would taste too much like lasagna, but I think the addition of the sour cream gave it it's own unique taste, not to mention all the different cheeses.  All of my teenage/adult children really enjoyed it.  A few notes:  This makes a lot so you may want to put something under the dish while cooking, as it bubbles over while cooking.  Definitely cover with foil to keep from drying out.  Depending on your oven bake time may be more like 35-40 minutes to heat thoroughly.  Will definitely make again-Thanks for the recipe!

text:
I cook all the time and this is the MOST REQUESTED recipe I've ever made. Never found a single person that didn't LOVE it, and they don't know why. It's the secret ingredients--sour cream and provolone--that make a world of difference. I've made it meatless, with ground sausage and ground beef, and sausage is our favorite but it's very rich. Just be sure to cover the noodles with sauce so the top ones don't get crunchy, and cover the whole thing with foil. I've cooked it twice as long by accident and it was still fine. Enjoy...everyone else will!

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this earlier this week for my son's 9th bday family get together. I was in a hurry and choose this last min and it still came out amazing. My plan was to double the recipe but it didn't work out that way. I put a layer of just sauce at the bottom of the pan then did the 1/2 the pasta. Next later was 1/2 the sauce/meat mixture which I did 2 and 1/2 jars of sauce instead of just 2 jars. Next layer was 6 slices of provolone cheese and 1/2 of the sour cream followed by the other half of pasta, 2cups of mozzarella cheese, and the last 1/2 of the sauce mixture. I used another 2 cups of shredded cheese on top. Baked it for an hr and everyone loved it. It was moist and cheesy. It fed 9 ppl and had enough left over for the 3 kids to eat it again the next day.

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674154.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Loved it. Here is what I modified: I added 4 large garlic cloves & a Tbs Italian seasoning to the meat (hot italian sausage) and onion. When the meat was cooked, I added one can sauce and let that simmer for maybe 20 min. While it simmered, I mixed an egg with a mixture of 3/4 lb ricotta & the remaining lb sour cream and about 3 heaping cups of chopped baby spinach to up the fiber content. I cooked the noodles (rigatoni) to al dente. To the noodles I added the other can sauce: stirred not shaken hehe! So here is how I did my layers and I filled a 9x13 pan and a smaller rectangular pan, not sure on the size, sorry. In the big pan, Half the.pasta/sauce mixture, half the ricotta mixture, half the sausage mixture, shredded mozzarella/Monterey jack cheese and a sprinkle of parmesan. I then filled my smaller dish to match. Viola! Super amazing.

text:
The quality of this recipe is highly dependent on the sauce that you use.  I found it to be a little bland with store-bought sauce.  It is a five-star recipe if you use John Chandler's World's Best Pasta Sauce recipe in place of the spaghetti sauce, ground beef, and onion.  It takes a bit of extra time to make the sauce from scratch but it is worth it.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
As with others I made some minor changes and it was awesome! Here's what I changed:
*added chopped garlic
*added red pepper flakes
*mixed the sourcream WITH the hot noodles and shredded cheese and added an egg and mixed up (leaving some cheese for layering and top) I used a combo of shredded asiago/parmesan/romano and topped with shredded mozzarella and parmesan mix)
*layered sauce/meat mix then noodle mix then cheese then sauce then cheese to top
*baked 40 min at recipe recommended temp in a throw away aluminum lasagna pan covered with foil then removed foil for nicely browned cheese top for another ten minutes.
Turned out magnifico!

https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674136.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is…basically the perfect recipe. Easy. Flexible. Hearty. Yummy. The more I eat the more I want. 
I made it with fusilli (spirals) so it could get in every nook and cranny. I also made according to directions except I used 1 cup sour cream and a little less marinara. I baked it 30 min UNcovered in one buttered 9x13 pyrex casserole . Both myself and my friend had 2 helpings and there was a ton left over.  About 7 meals total.  The only thing I may try next time is to add a bit of fresh minced garlic. 
By the way, it comes out tasting way better than the pictures look.  I don’t know why some of the pics looked soupy. Maybe I was right to use less marinara.
---------
Edit:
I made this a second time with a classico garlic sauce which was more chunky and it was not as good. Last time I used Classico regular marinara combined with a spicy one which was much better.

text:
I cover it first and bake for about 30 minutes and then remove the foil and continue to bake until it's bubbling and golden (like lasagna recipes advise). A step I figured out only after I had my husband follow the baking directions for tonight's dinner while I was at an appointment and it turned out just passable but undercooked in my opinion.   I've made it a few times and usually get compliments.  Tonight I was feeding four teenage boys and it was not as popular as it has been in the past.  I'm sure it was because it was undercooked.  (How many teenage boys have you met who don't eat seconds?)  
Overall it's a good basic ziti recipe and a crowd pleaser.  You can add what you like or make it meatless but just allow more time for baking it.

text:
I found this recipe years ago and it quickly became a recurring favorite. I am not a big fan of ricotta cheese so the sour cream and provolone were a nice change. The order of layering can affect the taste so try different orders to find the one you like best. I typically add garlic with when browning the beef and onion. This recipe will fill a 9x13 dish to the brim! So, be careful when layering. I have made this for groups of people as well as for just the family and it is always a hit. Great to have as leftovers.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
If I could, I would rename this recipe to "Weeknight Lasagne"!   It was a deliciously simple version of a normally very time consuming recipe.   I'm Italian, and my lasagne is a labor of love which starts with making my own sauce.   When I saw this recipe, I knew I had sauce in the freezer and decided to give it a go.   SO glad I did.   I was skeptical of the provolone/sour cream situation, but I think I prefer this now over the traditional ricotta mix I put together.   It binds up better and everyone loved it here.   Instead of the ground beef + onion, I just cooked up a pound of mild italian sausage for my meat.   Everything else was done per the recipe exactly.      I did a half recipe based on the volume and it was perfect for a family of 4 plus some leftovers for the next day.    This one is a KEEPER!

text:
YUMMY!
Made this for a pot luck and everyone loved it. Nothing left over.
Lots of flavor and the sour cream gives a nice creamy/smooth texture. The only change I made was I cut the ground beef in half (just personal preference), added a little garlic, and baked it cover. I removed the cover the last 10 mins so it could brown on top. I actually served it in a crock pot so it would stay warm during our party and it kept wonderful.

Display Name:

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674134.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family enjoyed this dish very much! After reading many of the reviews, I used an 11x15 baking dish and it was full. I did place a layer of meat sauce mixture to the bottom of the dish first, then ziti, then more sauce mixture then the sour cream. I added an egg and about 1/4 cup Parmesan Cheese with the sour cream before spreading. Then I placed the layer of provolone cheese,remaining ziti over that, rest of the sauce and topped with mozzarella and Parmesan cheeses. I also added fresh cut mushrooms and Italian seasoning to the sauce. I baked this covered for 30 minutes and then an extra 15 minutes uncovered in a 350 degree preheated oven. It was a big hit the little leftovers we had tasted just as good if not better the next day! The provolone and sour cream made this extra tasty...do not skip this!!

text:
This was heavenly!  I debated whether to use sour cream or ricotta, but went with the sour cream.  Fantastic!
Do not substitute.  It gave the dish just the right hint of a tang.  Lighter than ricotta.  I make my own sauce, so did not use jar sauce. This is a new favorite.  Great for company, too.  (yes, bake it covered, but remove foil last few minutes to brown the top.)  Forgot to mention we are gluten free, so I used Schar's gf penne.  Worked like a charm.  No one could tell any difference.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5677173.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
My family liked this dish. It does make a large amount though - enough for probably about 8 people - and a little goes a long way. I will try to freeze the leftovers, since some have said that it freezes well. 
I subbed in ricotta for the sour cream, omitted the provolone and used a bit more mozz, and added a chopped tomato to the sauce (to give it a bit more 'body'). 
I used Italian seasoned ground turkey instead of beef - and would also like to try it with spinach. 
I believe that sauce brand probably makes a difference in the outcome. (I used Newman's Tomato/Basil). Also, as with lasagna, it helps to let it cool for about 20 min. before serving - otherwise it could be 'watery'.

userID:
2991367
Display Name:
Nozdule
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0

0

3
favoritesCount:
102
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
YUM! This recipe made my day! It was super quick and easy to make. I definitely took other people's advice and baked it covered - which ensured it's juiciness. I also added a dash of Italian seasoning, crushed black pepper, crushed red chilies and 3 cloves of fresh garlic to the meat and onions while sautéing.   I also sprinkled fresh chopped basil on each layer, which gave the pasta a rich and irresistible aroma. Without these extra touches, I think it would've been a little bland for my taste and dry (hence 4 stars not 5).

What I loved about it was the sour cream and the provolone melted together - such a creative way of adding lingering creamy/cheesy flavour. This was an awesome dish, I will definitely be making it again in the near future.

Thanks for sharing!!

To tell the truth I haven't even tried it yet, but I had to write a review now.  Both my son and my husband love it and have asked for seconds already!  They both said it was good and my son said it's even better than his school that makes it.  I am so very happy about their reactions.  I used all the ingredients as above, the only difference I made was the layering proccess. I first put down a layer of sauce and then ziti and then the cheese and sour cream.  I covered with aluminum foil before putting it in the oven for 30 minutes @ 350.  It came out very moist and not dry in the least.  Experiment and enjoy!

text:
First let me just say I am not a big Italian/pasta person but my husband loves it so I decided to try this tonight - mostly because I was looking for something I could make without having to go to the store.  This was AWESOME!  I followed the recipie exactly with just a couple of exceptions:  I layered the sauce before the cheese as recommended by the other reviewers and I covered the dish while it was baking. I uncovered it the last ten minutes so the cheese would brown.  I also cooked it in a deep dish casserole dish - this made enough for all four of us big eaters to have two plates full plus we have enough for dinner tommorrow!  The sour cream was excellent - I dont like the texture of rigotta cheese so I loved using this instead.  Definately a keeper.

text:
I slightly misread the recipe and thought there would be another layer, so I ended up only adding half the amount of sour cream and provolone. Used crumbled sausage in place of hamburger, just my preference. I did not put any mozzarella on top initially; I covered it and baked for 30 minutes. Then I uncovered it, added a generous sprinkling of mozzarella and parmesan, and cooked for 10 additional minutes. I came out perfectly delicious. Don't be concerned about the sour cream-it just blends with the ingredients nicely. Great recipe!

Display Name:
Amanda Walker

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/1199449.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Made it tonight. Was awesome! Had to tweak based on what I had on hand. I didn't have jars of pasta sauce- had to kinda make it from scratch. 2 small cans of sauce, 2 cans of tomato paste, 1 can of spicy tomatoes(like Rotel) and two large tomatoes that were getting soft(i like firm tomatoes). I didn't have any provolone or Parmesan cheese, so I used what I had on hand - mozzarella sticks, shredded mozzarella, and 5 slices of cheddar(for the top). The finished product had a little bite to it, but it tasted like real Italian food - spicy and savory. Mixed with the ground beef was several spices; dry minced onions and garlic(yum), Mrs Dash, and parsley - while cooking. I think it turned out wonderful and I would definitely make this again!!! Very yummy and tasted awesome night one - can't wait to taste it after it sits for a day!

I love this recipe.  At first I thought I would miss the ricotta cheese but the sour cream is a great substitute. It serves a small army so I always halve the recipe for my family and bake in a 8x8 dish and it's perfect. I use sweet bulk Italian sausage instead of ground beef, light sour cream, and sliced mozzarella instead of shredded since I'm already at the deli buying the sliced provolone.  I also don't measure the parmesan cheese...just grate until I can't see the sauce anymore.  We love our parmesan cheese.
Review:
Rating:
5
dateLastModified:
2012-10-30T12:54:51.173

I noticed a lot of people said it was a lot of food, however I feed a husband and three kids so It was just enough left for him take some to work the next day. I was hesitant to you use the provolone  sour cream method instead of ricotta. However after reading a review by another user I went with it and it tasted amazing!! Great Recipe will be a staple at my house!!

text:
I have been making this recipe for years and ALWAYS get rave reviews. You have to use a good sauce. I am stuck on Emeril's homestyle marinara. I use 3 jars and about 1.5 lbs of ground meat. I let it simmer for about 2 hours so that the meat gets nice and soft. Everything else I follow exactly. The key is to make sure you have plenty of sauce then it will not dry out. And no...you do not need to cover it.

city:

None
text:
I was looking for something different in a pasta casserole and came across this recipe.  I tried it for dinner and what a hit it was!!!!  Easy, quick, and really tasty.  I served it with garlic bread and a green salad.  My family loved it so much that they devoured it that same night and we were only 3 people!  AND they asked me to make it again right away.  I followed the directions exactly except for one change.  I mixed the meat sauce with the pasta first and then layered the pasta, sour cream and cheese, ending with shredded Parmesan mixed with mozzarella on top.  Baked it for 45 minutes until the top was brown.  Wonderful!

text:
After making this I found it to be a great base recipe for baked ziti. However I noticed that at no time are spices added, nor do you drain the ground beef. Next time I will finely chop 2 cloves of garlic and add in with the onion and beef to cook, and toss in at least 2-4 Tbls of Italian seasoning. All so it may be easier after frying the beef to place in a wide pot to simmer with the sauce. Even a large frying pan gets a little crowded with this one.

text:
This is the BEST ziti I have ever had / made. I only made minor adjustments. I added minced garlic to the meat and onion mixture. I also pre-mixed the sour cream, parmesan cheese and mozzerella and then mixed it with the noodles. I layered half the noodle mixture first, then half the sauce and then put the sliced provolone, then the rest of the noodles and then the rest of the sauce. I also have only made ziti with ricotta in the past and I have to say I definately prefer this recipe. This one is going into my box and will be making again!

text:
This was AMAZING!  I have to admit, I was skeptical about sour cream in the recipe, but it works!  Both my husband and I devoured this over several days as it made excellent leftovers.  I thought I would bring some to family members to share since it made so much and is so hearty, but we were too selfish this time :)  Next time, we will invite everyone over.  I should mention that I did not use hamburger & onion, but instead swapped that with our favorite mini meatballs (size of marbles) from Graziano's in Des Moines, IA.  I used 2 jars of Gino's marinara sauce, which is a spicier flavor.  I am just not a fan of ground beef (my husband is) so this was a delicious compromise.  This is now on top of our list as one of our staple meals!  Thank you for sharing!

text:
I used cheddar and monterrey jack cheese.  I halved the recipe and it filled a 9x13 casserole dish.  I sprayed with Pam and put all of the ziti on the bottom. I then just put spoonfuls of the sour cream over the ziti and then a layer of cheddar cheese.  I browned ground turkey, added the onions and spaghetti sauce and poured that over the top and then added the layer of monterrey jack cheese.  My family of 5 + 1 more last night all loved it.  It was super easy to make after a long day.  Thanks so much!

Made this last night for the family!  Absolutely delicious!  I added some minced garlic (love garlic), garlic powder, and Italian seasonings to my sauce after adding it to the hamburger and let simmer just like recipe calls for.  Sour cream gives it the right taste (great for those who do not like ricotta cheese) and so does the provolone cheese (one of our favorite cheeses).  I will definitely make this again.

I have to admit, I made several changes, so I'm not sure I can say I made this recipe exactly.  However, the great thing about the recipe is that it is easily adaptable.
I used ricotta cheese instead of sour cream and shredded mozzerella instead of prvolone.  I like veggie meals, but this one is great with the ground beef - just makes it a little heartier.  I found it a little hard to tell when it was done, but I managed to get it just right (about as long as the recipe said).

text:
I have made this Baked Ziti many, many times. It is my go to meal for friends who have just had new babies. I usually split it in two smaller throw away containers- one to eat now and one to freeze and save for later. I have made it both with and without the ground beef and both versions are delicious. I, also, love to use homemade marinara sauce. I've had a really hard time finding ziti pasta, so I just use whatever big tubes that I can find. I, also, substitute plain yogurt for the sour cream.

text:
I love this recipe. It turns out great every time. The sour cream and provolone cheese adds a mild cheese flavor without overpowering the dish. I usually add 1/2lb. ground round & 1/2lb. mild italian sausage to the sauce. It's a great recipe for big parties. I just made it for 50 people in a roaster oven and it came out super moist. Lots of compliments.

text:
This Ziti was really good!  It had a wonderful flavor with the mixture between the provolone cheese, mozzarella cheese and the parmesan cheese.  The sour cream was a wonderful addition.  We like a lot of cheese so I bumped up the amounts and the parmesan cheese I have is the 3 cheese blend.  I covered it for the first 30 minutes and took the foil off for the last 5 minutes.  Very moist and flavorful dish!!  Thanks for submitting this!

I liked this, it had a very different taste than I was expecting. The sour cream and provolone were unexpected- I gave it 4 stars because it wasn't GREAT, and I did have to jazz it up a bit the second time I made it with more garlic and italian seasonings. I will make this again, but I think next time I will use half the amount of sour cream and provolone, and twice as much mozzarella. I thought it was even better the next day when I reheated the leftovers for lunch.

text:
I LOVE THIS RECIPE! Ive made this ziti several times. Ive made a few changes to my familys liking .. I add a roll of sausage in with the ground beef & brown it together, then when I add the sauce, I stir in ricotta cheese in with the sauce & let it simmer for about 10-15 minutes..  I toss the pasta with sour cream, & when I do my layering, I throw in some pepperonis. I use provolone cheese as well as mozzerella with my layers.. I serve it up with some fresh cut chives/green onions ... SOOO YUMMY !!!!

text:
I always get rave reviews whenever I make this!  I usually undercook the pasta by a minute or two because it will continue to cook in the oven. It tastes great without the meat, or with half ground beef/ground italian sausage for a more savory taste. Add some red pepper flakes if you like the heat. You can assemble this a day or two ahead of time, and just increase the baking time when you do pop it in the oven.

text:
This is an easy, delicious recipe. I added seasonings that I use in spaghetti sauce (Basil, Oregano, Marjoram, Oregano, Red Pepper Flakes, Garlic) and 2 T. of white sugar. I set aside 3 cups of the sauce, then mixed everything else with the cooked pasta, except for the Parmesan cheese. I put the pasta mixture into two 9" square pans, then topped each with 1-1/2 cups of sauce. I covered it with foil, and baked it. Yummy!

userID:
2502421
Display Name:
northernlightslover
isPro:
False
followersCount:
0
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
5
favoritesCount:
1
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674162.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I was looking for a quicker version of manicotti, which always takes so long because you have to stuff the noodles. This is how I made it:  3 cups noodles (dried), 1 1/4 lb lean ground turkey, 2 (26 ounce) jars spaghetti sauce, 15 oz low fat ricotta cheese, 8 oz low fat sour cream, 8 oz low fat mozarella cheese, 4 oz grated parmesan cheese, 1 egg, 2 tsp minced garlic, 1 tsp italian seasoning, 1/4 tsp ground nutmeg, Salt & Pepper to taste  I cooked the ground turkey with onion and garlic while I boiled the ziti. In a medium bowl I mixed together ricotta, cheeses, sour cream, egg, and seasonings. For the first layer I used sauce, so I wouldn't have to grease the pan. I then layered half the pasta (I reduced the pasta because there was way too much to fit in a 13 x 9 pan), then I layered with half the meat/onion mixture, and then half the cheese mixture. I repeated. I covered with foil, baked at 350 for 30 minutes. Then took out, sprinkled with additional cheese and baked until cheese was melted. Great dish, very creamy.
Review:
Rating:
3
dateLastModified:

Yummy!  Too bad this one is so difficult to convert into a "healthy" version.  Here are my substitutions: ground turkey, low-fat cheeses, and fat-free sour cream, whole wheat pasta, and reduced-fat Italian hard cheese blend.  I also added some chopped, fresh parsley to the sauce.  Not much else is possible -- it's still in the "comfort food" category and I will still happily eat it!

I used bertolli sauce (one vodka sauce one tomatoe basil), and I added 4 ounce of softened cream cheese to the sour cream mix.  I did as others suggested and put some sauce on the bottom of the pan, then I layered as the reciped stated.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
this is THE baked ziti here on the site.  awesome recipe, can't complain about a thing.  don't miss the sour cream & the provolone & if you want it to be really good, you need to use real parmesan & more than 2 Tbs. on top!  be aware that this probably won't fit well into a 9x13", i end up using a 9x13" + loaf pan to bake it all at once.  a bigger "lasagna" pan would be perfect.  i have never used 2 whole jars of spaghetti sauce, i think that's overkill, but try & see for yourself.  you don't have to cover this, it should be fine as long as you didn't skimp on the sauce & cover all the noodles adequately.

After reading a ton of other reviews, I decided to make this recipe exactly the way it was intended, with the sour cream and provolone, not with ricotta as many of you suggested.  I did not add any meat to my sauce, though.  I have to say, this was an amazing dish, full of robust flavor -- must have been the sour cream and provolone!  My husband and two kids (who are very picky) ate it up like crazy and everyone kept telling me how "yummy" it was.  So not only was it delicious, it was EASY and quick!  This is definitely a winner!

Hello All. I tried this today with the following changes. Ricotta and one egg mixed with the Ziti, No Provalone or Sour Cream. I Used Ragu Chuncky W/Muishroom for the sauce one of the big jars. I seasoned the meat while it browned with garlic powder and onion powder then drained it and Mixed it into the sauce and let that simmer for 15 mins. Sauce on the bottom Ziti mix next Mozz. Parm. and some garlic powder and oregano. Repeat Cover with foil and baked for a Half hour. My wife who said it was Ok Hates everything I cook so It must be pretty  good. I thought it was a really good tasteing way to warm up.

text:
Even though it has the same ingredients as the back of the ziti box, this recipe is great because of the order that it layers the ingredients. One layer of provolone and sour cream is much easier to assemble than the 2 layers they suggest on the box. This is super easy and very delicious -- and even picky kids love it. My daughter hates ricotta cheese, so the sour cream is a nice change.

I've been making this for years and always a big hit.  I substitute hot Italian sausage for the ground beef.  I up the provolone to 8oz. because I just order ½ # at the counter.  I go with either regular sour cream or reduced fat.  Doesn’t effect is one bit going reduced fat.  I’ve never tried fat free but probably wouldn’t be an issue.  I just eyeball the shredded mozzarella.

text:
I LOVE baked ziti! This was a nice, easy version for me to adapt to my family's preferences, and was also inexpensive to make. I used rotini noodles (easier for my little ones to get on a fork), omitted meat & provolone (for cost), and mixed noodles & sauce together prior to baking, as others suggested. I also covered the pan with foil up to the last 10 minutes, and it wasn't dry. I'll be making this often. I was leery since there were no added spices, but it was still very flavorful. I'll try it with provolone next time.

I'm not a very good cook usually and I was able to make this! I used fake meat crumbles to turn this dish vegetarian and my boyfriend said he couldn't even tell the difference! I also used Colby Jack cheese instead of provolone and added some chopped green peppers and some extra seasoning to the sauce. I halved the recipe because it was just for the two of us and we still have leftovers. I don't like ricotto cheese so I wouldn't even think about changing to that. The sour cream worked out wonderfully, even though I was skeptical! I couldn't even tell it was in there really! I will be adding this into our rotation of dishes. I can't wait to cook it for other people too!

userID:

Display Name:
motty

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/132452.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I love this recipe! The flavors are great and it's very simple to prepare. After making it several times, here are a few things that I would change (techniques mostly, not really to do with the flavors): 1) Mix the sour cream into the sauce while it's simmering. I don't like the taste of just sour cream as a layer. 2) Spread a small amount of sauce on the bottom of the pan to keep pasta from sticking. 3) Layer as follows: ziti, sauce, provolone, ziti, sauce mozzarella. 4) Forget the Parmesan. If you're like me, you don't use it that often and it just goes to waste. Why buy a whole package of Parmesan to use just 2 Tbsp?

text:
I love this easy recipe! I am making it tonight for 8 people...   I actually simmer/reduce the sauce for longer than 15 mins because I like my ziti to be pretty thick, but that is just personal preference. I also make it meat free because my boyfriend is a veggie... would love to try it with meat though!  Sauce is pretty easy to make- next time I will probably try to make this but make my own sauce instead of just jar of spaghetti sauce.   As far as covering it goes- yes do cover it for the bulk of the baking, but I uncover it towards the end to make the cheese look toasty.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Read other reviews, so after cooking ground beef with onion & italian seasonings, salt & pepper I mixed in the spaghetti sauce then mixed this( all except 1 full cup of it that I reserved) with the cooked ziti then put on the sour cream & layered the cheeses. Ended by topping with the very full cup of reserved meat sauce & sprinkled on generously the parmesan cheese. Sprayed tin foil with cookin oil spray & covered. Placed in preheated 350* oven on a large preheated cookie sheet & baked covered for 20 minutes, uncovered & finished baking until top was slightly browned. Served with sauted zucchini squash & garlic toast for sides.Two grown men & myself found this very tasty with enough left over to freeze for another meal in the future. Thanks for a good recipe.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
The secret layer of sourcream and layered provolone give this recipe an edge over traditional baked ziti. When sauce combine with ricotta, the cheese can dry out and absorb the sauce. This method keeps everything bubbly and juicy. The melted cheeses are not lost in the dish. Reheating leftovers yields the same results of a moist and flavorful baked ziti. A genrous sprinkling of fresh chopped basil and/or parsley once it comes out of the oven adds a nice flavor and presentation. I have also blended my sourcream with goat cheese and cottage cheese before to add more tang and flavorful creaminess. But the recipes in its' original form is just perfect too!

Absolutely delicious!!! A couple of things I did different, was use only 1 jar of pasta sauce. I actually had 2 on hand, but felt that it would be a bit too runny if I used 2. For my lactose intolerant husband, I used veggie provolone, mozzerella, parmesean and imitation sour cream. He loved it and could not tell the difference!

text:
Absolutely a favorite recipe!  Unlike some, I NEVER bake this covered and it is never dry.  The reason that some might find it dry is the fact that most spaghetti sauce sold in jars have lowered the amount in each jar!  Be careful that you add at least what this recipe calls for!  I have NEVER changed this recipe, except for substituting ground turkey for the ground beef.

text:
I liked this; just finished a huge plate of it. But it was not the amazing taste or flavor I expected from reviews. I thought I should season the meat, but decided to just follow the recipe to the letter (besides adding a dollop of tomato paste and some fresh basil to the sauce). I wish I would have followed my instincts. I think some salt, pepper, garlic, sage, thyme, oregano, etc. in the meat would have enhanced the flavor. I also thought perhaps I would have had different results with a more expensive, flavorful spaghetti sauce, and that was why the recipe by itself was so great. Hopefully next batch (since it's so huge!) will be more flavorful.

text:
I made this tonight with some changes, and it got rave reviews and was instantly added to my family's "favourites" list! I used a homemade tomato sauce I had made a few nights earlier with fresh tomatoes, and followed other reviewers by using half lean beef, half hot italian sausage browned with onion and garlic. Added 1 can of sliced mushrooms, too. Used mozzarella slices with mozza and medium cheddar for the grated cheese because I couldn't find provalone. Other than that, ALL GOOD!! For those having trouble with spreading the sour cream, whip it a bit first in a bowl to cream it.

city:

region:

country:
None
text:
I agree with Bayou Gator (most helpful review), don't change anything about this recipe. I know many people are probably use to using ricotta in a recipe like this and that sour cream + provolone may sound weird, BUT after the sour cream and provolone cook together you basically end up with a cheese mixture that looks identical to ricotta (I think the heat curdles the sour cream) but taste tons better. I did use whole wheat penne (no ziti to be found) and light sour cream (Daisy brand, very good and thick sour cream). The next time I make this I am going to add diced pepperoni and brown with the beef and onion. Thanks for the easy recipe!

text:
This was a delicious tasting Baked Ziti and very easy to prepare.  The only thing I changed was how I layered my dish.  I mixed the pasta sauce mixture with the noodles before layering.  Than I put noodles with sauce, cheese, noodles with sauce and parmesaen cheese.  This way the noodles weren't dried out and the flavoring was mixed very well throughout the ziti.  I will make this again.

text:
This recipes was surprisingly good.  I also changed a few things that made it great - used ricotta cheese instead of sour cream and added a few extra cloves of chopped garlic.  I used a four cheese sauce that went very nicely with this recipe.  I would not have known to cover this dish either without reading several of the other reviews.  I depend a lot on details like that, so it is important to include as you never know what little thing is going to completely change the recipe.   Also, I used penne pasta instead of ziti.  I'm not entirely sure that there is a difference unless it is in size, but I was unable to find penne pasta.  In any case, this was a very easy and tasty recipe that I will definitely make again.

city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this pasta according to LP's review, layering like the suggestion and it came out very good like that, nice and moist, covered it too. I also used the ricotta/egg instead of the sour cream. However I give it 3 stars according to my "doctoring" of the recipe. I thought from the start that it would be bland - no spices, what's with that, onion is not enough!!!! So I added oregano and basil to the sauce and a few dashes of Louisiana pepper sauce, just 5 or 6. Mind you I DOUBLED the recipe to fit a large All- Clad turkey roasting pan. The result - bland sauce. I didn't add enough of the spices. My fault. But I also put 8 cups of mozz. cheese in this thing, no way 6 oz for a regular batch would be enough if you like cheese!!!! and the 8 c. I used was still not enough in my husband's eyes. (What can I say, he loves mozz. cheese). There will be a next time, but I think I will add more oregano and basil to the sauce, and a bit more hot sauce as I want to have a "kick" to the recipe. Made plenty, and I froze the rest, reheat frozen in the casserole covered at 350 for 1 hour. Good recipe - thanks!!!!

text:
I thought this was good. I've seen this recipe on the back of a Ziti pasta box at the store.  For some viewers comments about using Ricotta, we all add and take things away from a recipe to suit our liking.  I personally make this dish and lasagna with fat free Cottage Cheese because Fat free tends to be dryer then 1/2 or full fat.  If you taste plain cottage cheese vs. sour cream, they are very similiar in taste.  This recipe is really good and personally don't like  using ricotta because I think it's dry unless of course you are getting the freshly made Ricotta from a special food store.  Thanks for sharing.

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5614259.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was delicious with the changes I made.  I'm giving it 4 stars because I think it would have been a bit bland without the modifications below:  I used 1/2 lb ground beef and 1/2 lb. hot Italian sausage.  Instead of layering the ingredients, I saved time by mixing the cooked pasta with the tomato sauce, 1 cup sour cream, and about half of the cheese.  I also added salt, pepper, and other Italian seasonings.  I added the rest of the cheese on top, and removed the aluminum foil for about 5 minutes at the end so the cheese got lightly browned.  I put this in a 9x13 pan but it was nearly overflowing, so I would suggest cutting in half or using 2 pans.  It turned out really well and is great as leftovers too.

Absolutely the best baked ziti I have ever eaten. The sour cream and provolone add so much more flavor and moisture than the traditional ricotta. I used ground sausage instead of ground beef, and added in three cloves of minced garlic with the onion and meat. text:
I don't agree with the replacement of ricotta and removing any of the cheeses.  Although this might not be "authentic" Italian it's still a really good ziti recipe that everyone I serve to loves.  Nobody even knows the sour cream is sour cream they think it is ricotta.  Also, you do not have to bake it covered for the fear of drying out like previous post states.  As long as you cover all the noodles with the sauce you should be fine.  I have made this dish several time and never covered it.

country:
None
text:
Wow! Yummy! Yummy!! This was my first time making ziti.  I used fresh mozzarella, provolone & Parmesan  cheese.  I used 1/2 sour cream & 1/2 ricotta cheese. When browning the meat I tossed 3 tbsp of fresh minced garlic, followed by some basil, oregano, garlic powder, onion powder, pepper and some salt.  Be picky when choosing the spaghetti sauce.  I chose Napa Valley Bistro-tomato & basil.  Very tasty!  I made my own garlic bread. French bread, 5 tbsp of melted butter, 3 tbs of olive oil, 3 tbsp of fresh garlic, & basil. Spread over French bread and bake.  Wonderful!

text:
This is a VERY good basic recipe.  I was looking for something to use up the ingredients I already had around the house, and this fit the bill.  I only changed a few things.  I substituted ricotta cheese for the sour cream, I cut out the ground beef and just went vegetarian, and I made my own spaghetti sauce.  

Also, because it is only my husband and I, I cut the recipe in half.  He LOVED it, couldn't stop commenting about it.  In fact, he commented about it again the next morning!

This was really yummy! Biggest change I made: you definitely need to mix the sauce mixture with the noodles before putting it in the pan. Otherwise it will end up being extremely dried out. This was delicious and I will definitely make it again. Also, this makes far too much for just two people so if I make it again, I may only make half as much.

text:
This was really good! Firstly I changed the recipe for 4 servings since everyone said this made alot. I also used meatballs I had in the freezer in place of the hamburger and didn't add onion as the meatballs already had some. I followed others advise and put the sauce ontop of the noodles and mixed it in on the first layer only. Then I followed with the cheese and sour cream. Also I did not grease the dish in anyway at all. I also covered it but next time I won't as this was really "saucy". My DH LOVED this and ate the rest for lunch today. And he never eats leftovers.

text:
My first time for baked ziti.  Needed to use up some previously prepared Lots O' Veggies Sausage Spaghetti Sauce.  Since the sauce had a bit of meat, I didn't use additional meat.  We like this recipe, although I didn't have the proper dish.  (Only had a deep casserole available.)  The only problem I had was that the sliced cheese made a definite layer, in places a little chewy...and maybe not enough sauce on the first layer, but that may have been because of the dish I used.  Overall we really enjoyed this recipe and agree that it's a great alternative to lasagna:  same concept, many of the same ingredients, with a lot less time and trouble.

text:
This was easy and delicious. I was skeptical about the sour cream, but really glad I used that and not ricotta. Didn't need a ton, so I halved everything and followed the recipe except for 2 small things.  I had a leftover cooked hot Italian sausage that I diced up and added to the meat sauce.  That gave things a nice little kick. I also mixed just a couple of scoops of sauce in with the pasta before layering so they weren't dry. It all fit perfectly in an 8x8 Pyrex dish and still cooked for the 30 minutes covered with foil.  Can't wait to make this again. Thanks!

Display Name:
Emily

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/global/features/10.gif
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This recipe is delicious!  Tonight was the second time I have made it, and it turned out even better than the first time.
Per some suggestions in other reviews, I added a tablespoon of minced garlic to the ground beef as it was cooking.  Also, I bought one huge jar of Prego traditional rather than 2 16 oz ones.  This gave me a little bit of extra sauce, which I used to coat the bottom of the pan before adding the noodles.  I also added the sauce on top of the noodle layers, rather than on top of the provolone layer.  For the mozzarella on top, I used 2 cups instead of just 6 oz (I prefer reallt cheesey dishes).  
I only cooked it for 45 minutes uncovered, which allowed the mozzarella and permesan to brown to perfection.  The dish is huge, so definitely be prepared to have lots of leftovers (I only made it for two).

5

text:
We have made this twice now and really enjoy this recipe.  I omit the provolone cheese (just to make it one less thing I have to buy since it's the only thing we don't regularly have on hand at our house,) and the second time I made it I also added some spices to the meat to jazz it up a little bit.  This ziti is a lot more moist than the recipe I've used in the past, but my husband really prefers moist ziti so it's perfect for us.  Thnaks for the recipe!

text:
It was good as a recipe but like all recipes you add what you like to make it supurb.  I gave it 5 starts because it fits the bill for taste, practicality, cost, and it's a great base recipe to experiment with.  I layered the noodles, provolone slices (they were cheaper, then used the mozerella and 1/2C sour cream (which I mixed together).  SoI had minimal rotating and it was like well mixed lasagna :0)  And I find it easier than lasagna.  Used ricotta instead of sour cream 2nd time and was still good.

KNOCKOUT recipe. so delicious.

text:
I understand why this has been so highly rated.  It is so easy, quick, and tastes like you slaved all day.  So much easier than lasagna!  I used mild italian sausage, roasted garlic pasta sauce, and layered as others did with the sauce on top of the ziti.  I covered with foil but uncovered for the last 5 minutes to let some of the cheese on top brown a little.  I also let it stand for about 5 minutes so it would be less runny.  Excellent!  I plan on making this for a large group (24) because it is so easy.

userID:
611167
Display Name:
Lost in the Kitchen
isPro:
False
followersCount:
2
followingCount:
0
madeRecipesCount:
1
favoritesCount:
13
recipesCount:
0
reviewsCount:
0
photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674158.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is a great recipe that I will use many times in the future.  I’m a beginner, though, and I even managed to make a mistake with this simple recipe, yet it turned out great.  I took the advice of some other reviewers and replace half the ground beef with hot Italian sausage (it definitely adds some great color to the flavor) and added a couple of cloves of fresh chopped garlic.  Also, I poured the sauce mixture directly on top of the ziti noodles before adding the provolone cheese.  Next time, I’m going to add another ¼ - ½ lb. of meat to this to suit my particular tastes.  My mistake was that when the recipe calls for you to start with half the ziti and half the sauce for the first layer, I just assumed that it only called for half the provolone as well.  Wrong!  I just didn’t read carefully, so the rest of my provolone went on top with the mozzarella and grated Parmesan.  It still turned out great and tasted very good!  (See picture!)

text:
This was sooo good!!!  I made a few changes since I am a vegetarian.  I used veggie ground round instead of ground beef.  I also added 3 cloves of garlic, 1/2 tsp crushed red peppers, and 1 tbsp italian spice to the sauce mix.  I didn't have provolone cheese so I just used mozzarella and a little bit of the prepackaged shredded mexican cheese mix.  I wasn't sure how the sour cream was going to taste in this dish but I must say it was absolutely delicious!!!  Definitely will make this again!

text:
Again, this was a recipe I had never tried before, but my family loves pasta. Instead of layering this like the recipe calls for, I mixed all the ingredients except for the cheese in a bowl then spread one layer topped with cheese and the spread the second. I did this because i wanted the pasta to be coated in the sauce. I also added Italian Seasonsing, Basil, and Oregano to the sauce. I thought it came out pretty good, but I was amazed by my Husband & his brother's reaction....they couldn't stop talking about it and they said it was the best meal I've made so far! I served with classic garlic bread. This recipe makes a ton so if you don't want leftovers cut it in half.

I made this last night for some friends, and it was a big hit!  Fast and easy to make.  I added 1lb of hot Italian sausage and 1 can of petite diced tomatoes since everyone said the sauce wasn't enough.  This dish came out perfect.  I was afraid the hot suasage would be too spicy, but since I mixed it with the sauce and the beef, it added some great flavor.  The sour cream gave it a great, rich taste!  I made it earlier in the day, and just put it in the refrig until time to cook.  I will definately be making this again!

Very Good! My son thinks it's lasagna...whatever makes him eat! Thanks for the recipe. ***UPDATE*** I made this for a luncheon at work and put it in the crock pot. I cooked everything the night before but didn't mix the noodles with the sauce and cheese. I layered it in the crock pot in the morning, turned it on high for the first hour and then down to low and by lunchtime...it was gone! There are never any leftovers!

text:
I love this recipe!! I made two for a potluck, one meatless & one Italian Sausage and EVERYONE loved it. The sour cream actually goes well with it, I wouldn't skip it -- but I did substitute 1/2 of the sour cream with ricotta cheese. I also added fresh garlic to the mix. It all turned out so delish! Some people reviewed this recipe and said it was bland. I think if you use a plain spaghetti sauce, it will be bland with no added seasonings. I used Garlic & Herb flavored sauce for my vegetarian one, and used Italian Sausage & Garlic flavored sauce for the other. 5 stars!!

I liked that this dish was easy to prepare, and the ingredients weren't terribly expensive. I substituted ground beef with Boca crumbles because I don't eat red meat. I also sauteed 4 cloves of minced garlic with the onion. At the suggestion of another reviewer, I added other spices to the sauce. I chose onion powder, black pepper, basil, and oregano. By mistake, I only used one of the jars of sauce, but it still turned out good. I served this with a garlic bread recipe found on allrecipes. My husband said that I outdid myself this time. Thanks for a good recipe!

region:

country:
None
text:
Excellent. I made tonight for dinner. Actually I doubled it and put in my huge roasting pan, so we would have lots of leftovers, and I could freeze some too. Too save time, I didn't layer it, I simply mixed everything together. I also used 1 lb. ground turkey and 1 lb. sweet ground italian sausage instead of ground beef. Sargento has a mozzarella/provolone shredded mix so I just used that. I stirred in 3  (26. oz each) cans of spaghetti sauce, and also stirred in some italian seasoning and fresh garlic. On top of everything, I poured a 4th final can over and then sprinkled on a little extra cheese. Put foil on top and baked 40 minutes. Will make again.

city:

region:
None
country:
None
text:
I made this last night, and it was great!  My picky husband ate 2 big servings.  I made a couple of modifications, though.  I used only 1 jar of spaghetti sauce to the pound of ground beef. The sauce I used was a spinach and cheese tomato sauce.  It was wonderful to sneak in some green stuff!  I added just a little extra tomato sauce from a can to make sure the recipe was saucy enough. (2 jars would be way too much here!)  Also, I skipped the provolone entirely and used shredded Italian 4 cheese blend throughout with a little shredded sharp cheddar thrown in for contrast.  The sour cream is the key here--so do not skimp on it!

I made this last night and it was the best baked ziti I've ever had.  My experience has always been that baked pasta dishes tend to be on the dry side, but not so with this one.  I'm assuming this was due to the sour cream, of which I was a little leary, but it really was a nice change from ricotta.  This recipe made a lot, but that wasn't a problem, because everyone had seconds and killed the leftovers today.  Thanks for a great recipe!

text:
Just made this last night and it was excellent!!  Bringing it to a house full of boys tonight, Im sure it wont last long!!  I doubled the recipe and still had some left over.  To the recipe I added tons of fresh garlic and used three jars of tomato basil pasta sauce in with the beef.  Then I layered it starting with a mixture of one jar marinara with 1/2 the ziti, put a layer of canned diced tomatoes, then 1/2 the beef sauce mixture, the provolone and sour cream, then the rest of the ziti, mozarella, beef sauce, and parmesan!  Cover definitely!!

This recipe was fantastic. Not only was it easy, it was delicious. I did make a few minor changes, I used 1 and a half lb of pasta (couldn't find Ziti!!) but used a similar tubular pasta. Used 3 bottles of sauce, added some cottage cheese with the sour cream, and added some chopped mushrooms and garlic. This fed a group of six people with big appetites...with about 4 servings left over. This was my first time making this dish, and it was a big hit with everyone. I also served the "Pepperoni bread" (also found at All Recipes) and Caesar salad. Yum

I mixed the noodles and sauce (i used homemade and I used a lot more than the recipe called for) together.  I added half of the noodle mixture to the 
9 x 13 pan.  Then added 8 oz of shredded mozarella and provolone cheese.  I added the sour cream, then topped with the remaining noodles.  I topped the whole thing with 8 oz of the cheese mixture and baked.  It was super easy and the leftovers were great!

"DON'T add sour cream" AND "leave the mozzarella on TOP" (instead of the sauce & the parmesean, (as this recipe states to do). Delicious, yes, but probably won't make again,this way.

This was really delicious! I used 1 lb 4 oz of ground turkey because that was how much was in the package. city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
Great recipe!!  Some changes I made were:  I substituted a half pound of Jimmy Dean's hot sausage for half the hamburger. I used a pre-grated mix of mozzarella and provolone cheeses and I added about 3 cloves of garlic to the onion-meat mixture as I was browning it.  Be sure to cover the dish in foil or it dries out.  It makes a lot, but I was able to fit it all into a rectangle cake pan.  With bread and a salad, this would feed 8-10 people.  I will definitly make this again and again.

text:
OMG Delicious! I made this for a dinner party yesterday and it was a huge hit! I made 2 batches. One with ground turkey and one w/ just mushrooms. On both batches I used Barillo Spag sauce and sauteed an onion and garlic and added some pepper flakes and other spices and simmered for 15 minutes. I think the key is to use the extra spices and good pasta sauce. Make sure the pasta is al dente. I also used extra cheese. I'll be making this for xmas! thanks!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674151.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This is fabulous!!  I scaled the recipe in half and also cut down on the cheese and sour cream because too much fat does not agree with my system.  I made my own sauce by sauteeing minced onion and garlic in olive oil, then adding a can of crushed tomatoes, basil, salt and pepper.  I prefer this simple sauce to store bought, most of which I find overpowering with spices.  For the meat, I crushed some home made seasoned meatballs into the sauce.  Assembly: I mixed the pasta, sauce, sour cream and half the mozzarella together.  Provolone in the middle and mozzarella & shredded parmesan on top.  I baked the dish covered for half the time.  YUM!  Next time I'll sneak some spinach into the concoction.

text:
This was very good. My husband does not care for sour cream so I added more shredded cheese to make up for any lack in flavor. Don't be afraid to load it on...I thought I was using too much and it turns out that it was not enough. I also used an Italian four cheese blend, which I definetly recommend. I don't like onions so I used a ton of minced onions instead and also added some garlic salt to the hamburger meat mixture for added flavor and it was yummy! The recipe stated it took an hour to make, but it sure didn't seem that long!!

text:
I used wheat rotini because the store was out of wheat ziti, but i think the rotini is better anyway because it holds onto the sauce better.  I also left out the meat and provolone and added a bit more mozzarella.  I scaled the recipe down to 4 servings but the finished product even without the meat seemed more like 6 servings.  I thought the sour cream added a great flavor and I used my favorite pasta sauce.  All in all this recipe was great, I ate almost the whole batch in an hour!  I didnt think the leftovers were nearly as good however.  Best eaten immediatley after making.

text:
Very good.  I liked the sour cream/provolone cheese combo in the middle layer.  I did not have quite 6 oz. of provolone and it made a difference - you need the full 6 oz.  I took the advise of other reviews and only used 1 1/2 jars of spaghetti sauce and should have stuck with the 2 jars as in the recipe.  I used the ridged ziti and it soaked up the sauce.  Layer as follows:  ziti, sauce, provolone, sour cream, ziti, sauce, parmesan cheese and then mozzarella.  Took to a potluck and it was all eaten.  Someone said it tasted just like ziti at Fazoli's.

country:

text:
This recipe was good.  I think I may have expected a bit more.  I scaled it down to 4 servings through the 'scale down' feature on the site and omitted the meat.  I sauteed onion and garlic together and then added the sauce.  Barilla makes a sauce called Al Forno-Italian Baking Sauce.  I use this sauce with all my baked pasta dishes and it is excellent. I sometimes add some left over red wine to the sauce near the end of simmering.  I think the next time I will use more cheese and sour cream to make up for not using meat.  The half recipe called for 3/4 sour cream, but it could have used 1 1/4 cup.  Instead of 3 oz. each of the provolone and mozzerella in the half recipe, it could be 6 ozs.  Sauce amount was perfect, but probably will need a bit more with added cheeses. I will make it again.

This recipe is superb. I halved the recipe for my family of four and had plenty - plus leftovers!  I chose to use just Prego sausage and garlic and it gave a very meaty hearty flavor which my husband really liked.  It turned out tasting like a really great lasagna but was sooooo much easier to make and so much easier for my kids to eat than traditional lasagna.  Like lasagna, just be sure to keep your dish covered until the last 5 minutes so that it stays nice and moist.  Very Yummy!  Goodbye lasagna hello baked ziti!

text:
WOW...I didn't know homemade ziti could taste so good.  I made it exactly as stated and it turned out perfectly.  My husband, kids, and drop-in company LOVED it.  Hubby wanted me to make it again the next night!!
For those few who rated the recipe low, I think the key may be to use the very best sauce you can.  I used one jar of Classico Four Cheese and one jar of Classico Sausage.  Any reciped an only be as good as the ingredients you start with!
Can't say enough good things about this recipe.  It tasted just as good or better than restaurant ziti!!

text:
I also was leery of the sour cream/tomato sauce mixture but that combo was the best feature.  It tasted much better than most recipes that call for ricotta.  Our family loved it...even the toddler!  Next time I will try and add more veggies and experiment with some lower fat ingredients.  I used half ground beef and half Italian sausage, which was good but I think no ground beef and all Italian sausage would be better.  It needed a little bit more spice.  This is going to become a staple!  Thanks!

I needed a ziti recipe for a special occassion and found this one.  I was asked to leave the meat out for a vegetarian guest.  I made a test batch to make sure the hostess liked it.  I added an extra 4oz. of mozzarella cheese to make up for the meat.  The hostess loved it and so did my family.  She even requested I make extra as she thought the kids will eat this over other foods being served.  I'm giving her a copy of the recipe at the bridal shower as I'm sure she will make it many times and I know that will please my son. Note - I used Hunt's canned sauce instead of jarred. This recipe is more moist than others. Enjoy!

text:
O my gosh!- I went to the grocery store and was just going to make spaghetti or lasagna or something with pasta- i just KNEW i had mozzarella and parmesan cheese in the fridge- well wouldn't you know..I boiled the pasta ( which i didn't have the ziti...i had a differnt kind of wavy noodle some other type of macaroni pasta...???) i used the sour cream ( fat free BTW-) and i used cheese sticks i had ..i grated them up - (it was the kind with the mozzarella and cheddar0 and i had cream cheese and grated parmesan in the can- 

all i can say is YUM! - i added onion powder and minced garlic when i was browning the ground beef, i added a touch of sugar and some more Italian seasonings-  substituted the grated cheese sticks in place of provolone/mozzarella in the bag- then put chunks of cream cheese ( yes i was worried...cream cheese in a pasta dish...don't know if i have ever heard of that...but i had to put some other cheese!- didn't want to try american cheese slices!)- i put the other half of sauce on top of the cream cheese, covered with a zillion shakes of the canned parmesan cheese...

just tasted it...WOW!

next time i will have all of the other cheeses, AND the cream cheese mixed into the sour cream, might also add the cottage cheese too!

I really don't think this dish could be bad!Even if you don't have all of the ingredients!!!!

text:
This is a very good recipe - good solid Italian
comfort food that everybody loves!  We have 
made it probably half a dozen times - sometimes
just for ourselves and sometimes for our families.
*Note*:  Unless you are really watching fat, I
recommend *not* using fat free sour cream in this.
My in-laws bought such when we made it at their
house, and it greatly reduced the taste - too
costly for the amount of fat per serving saved.
Fight that battle elsewhere...

Delicious!  I was out of provolone, so I added more mozzarella, and threw in a little ricotta too.  Very, very good.  Company raved.  Can't wait to have the leftovers!

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674133.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
This was a good baked ziti recipe.  But, I made some changes based on comments by other posters as well as what my husband and I like.  These are the variations that I made: 1) I used the "Best Marinara Sauce Yet" recipe from this site rather than the jars.  2) I used ricotta cheese mixed with one egg instead of the sour cream.  And, I mixed the ricotta and egg in with the cooked ziti.  3) I cubed the mozzarella rather than shredding it.  4) I added two cloves of minced garlic while browning the meat.  5) I used half a pound of beef and half a pound of pork sausage.  6) I put a thin layer of marinara sauce on the bottom of thye baking pan.  7) At the top of the ziti, I covered it with slices of provolone, slices of mozzarella, and grated cheese.  8) I baked it covered for 30 minutes, and uncovered for another 15 minutes.  
With these variations, it turned out great!!!

text:
This makes quite a big dish of pasta.  I tried to half the recipe, but after only one layer, I ended up having to use a second dish for the overflow.  I may have used too much beef.  I sautéed green pepper, mushrooms, and minced garlic with the onions for extra veggies.  I would also recommend adding some italian seasonings to it as well.  I did not add the provolone and it still tasted great.  This dish is open to adaptations, so don't be afraid to experiment with the ingredients!  My wife does not usually like "lagasna-type" dishes, but enjoyed this one.

This recipe always brings rave reviews from even my pickiest eaters.  I use l/2 Italian sausage, crumbled fine while browning with l/2 lb. ground beef. I add rosemary, basil, oregano, and garlic powder to the jars of sauce.  I also use 3/4 c. Ricotta mixed with 3/4 c. sour cream.  This is
excellent!

text:
I thought this was really tasty. We added a couple of zucchini, an entire bag of baby spinach (gotta get the veggies in there so the hubbster doesn't notice!) and we used sausage instead of ground beef. The store was out of regular provolone and only had smoked, so I skipped that and used mozzarella instead. Very hearty and good. Was even better the second day!

The single recipe makes A LOT, so be warned. You could easily halve the recipe and make a 9x9 pan. Spices were good and it was relatively quick and easy. The family really liked it!

Display Name:
JUDITH

photo:
https://images.media-allrecipes.com/userphotos/50x50/5674147.jpg
city:
None
region:
None
country:
None
text:
I varied the recipe for taste and because of ingredients I had on hand. I added 2 cloves of minced garlic and sauteed with the onion. I used only one jar of spaghetti sauce and added 1/2 cup water (can't imagine using two jars of sauce... would be too much liquid for the other ingredients and would overflow a 9x13 pan). I added a small can of sliced mushrooms to the beef and sauce mix and sprinkled some basil into it. I mixed together 3/4 cup of sour cream and 3/4 cup of Ricotta (I didn't have any provolone).  Mixing them together made it easier and quicker to spread over the ziti.  As other reviewers suggested, I covered with foil and baked 30 minutes.  Then I removed foil and baked another 10 minutes.  Turned out super!  My husband raved!  Fairly quick putting it together and results were worth it! It's a keeper!

country:
None
text:
It's a great basic recipe for ziti; i used my own meat sauce with ground turkey and reduced-fat sourcream and my hubby and his son loooved it. And said would have it again and again in the same week! Now the only problem i encountered was when i was portioning it out the sourcream looked curdled kinda like ricotta cheese; did this happen to anyone else? It's no biggy, but i was hoping it would be creamier. Very tasty all the same. Oh, i did cover it with a buttered foil cover so it wouldn't dry out, i think it helped and then removed it at the end of cooking and let the cheese melt for another 5-10 minutes. Yoo could use the broiler if you wanted that crispy golden touch. This one is a keeper. Thnx

region:
None
country:
None
text:
Very good recipe.  I used a larger pan so it would all fit without overflowing. I used half Italian sausage & half ground beef.  I added Italian seasoning and minced garlic to the meat. I mixed the ziti in with the sauce before layering.  I reduced the sour cream to only about 1 cup.  I used 2 1/2 jars of sauce (Classico).   Everyone enjoyed it.  It also reheats well for leftovers the next day.

We used to make something similar to this at Papa Gino's. (an italian fast food restaurant in our area)  It is such a great recipe.  I use fat free ricotta as well as light mozzarella so its a little healthier.  I also broil it for about five minutes after cooking time so that the cheese gets nice and crispy.  My husband asks for this every week!  Thanks

text:
I was so excited to find a recipe for baked ziti in the "Hall of Fame." I have always loved ziti but never tried making it myself. This was great! The sour cream helps to make the sauce very creamy. As many others have said, this makes a HUGE amount of food and it is a tight fit in a 9x13 pan. I was glad to see one review where someone used only 1 jar of sauce instead of 2 and it worked fine. I think I'll try that next time--both to help stop the bit of overflow in the oven and also because it was a tad bit too saucy for me. But, all in all, YUM!
